CAB. I.

English: The book of the generation of Jesus Christ, the son of David, the son of Abraham.
Manx: Lioar Sheeloghe Yeesey Creest, mac Ghavid, mac Abraham.

English: Abraham begat Isaac; and Isaac begat Jacob; and Jacob begat Judas and his brethren;
Manx: 2 Hooar Abraham Isaac, as hooar Isaac Jacob, as hooar Jacob Judas as e vraaraghyn.

English: And Judas begat Phares and Zara of Thamar; and Phares begat Esrom; and Esrom begat Aram
Manx: 3 As hooar Judas Phares as Zarah rish Thamar, as hooar Phares Esrom, as hooar Esrom Aram.

English: And Aram begat Aminadab; and Aminadab begat Naasson; and Naasson begat Salmon;
Manx: 4 As hooar Aram Aminadab, as hooar Aminadab Naassoon, as hooar Naassoon Salmon.

English: And Salmon begat Booz of Rachab; and Booz begat Obed of Ruth; and Obed begat Jesse;
Manx: 5 As hooar Salmon Booz rish Rachab, as hooar Booz Obed rish Ruth, as hooar Obed Jesse.

English: And Jesse begat David the king; and David the king begat Solomon of her that had been the wife of Urias;
Manx: 6 As hooar Jesse David yn ree, as hooar David yn ree Solomon ree-ish v’er ny ve ben Urias.

English: And Solomon begat Roboam; and Roboam begat Abia; and Abia begat Asa;
Manx: 7 As hooar Solomon Roboam, as hooar Roboam Abia, as hooar Abia Asa.

English: And Asa begat Josaphat; and Josaphat begat Joram; and Joram begat Ozias;
Manx: 8 As hooar Asa Josaphat, as hooar Josaphat Joram, as hooar Joram Ozias.

English: And Ozias begat Joatham; and Joatham begat Achaz; and Achaz begat Ezekias;
Manx: 9 As hooar Ozias Joatham, as hooar Joatham Achaz, as hooar Achaz Ezekias.

English: And Ezekias begat Manasses; and Manasses begat Amon; and Amon begat Josias;
Manx: 10 As hooar Ezekias Manasses, as hooar Manasses Amon, as hooar Amon Josias.

English: And Josias begat Jechonias and his brethren, about the time they were carried away to Babylon:
Manx: 11 As hooar Josias Jechonias as e vraaraghyn, mygeayrt y tra v’ad goit ersooyl nyn gappeeyn gys Babylon.

English: And after they were brought to Babylon, Jechonias begat Salathiel; and Salathiel begat Zorobabel;
Manx: 12 As ayns earish yn chappeeys ayns Babylon, hooar Jechonias Salathiel, as hooar Salathiel Zorobabel.

English: And Zorobabel begat Abiud; and Abiud begat Eliakim; and Eliakim begat Azor;
Manx: 13 As hooar Zorobabel Abiud, as hooar Abiud Eliakim, as hooar Eliakim Azor.

English: And Azor begat Sadoc; and Sadoc begat Achim; and Achim begat Eliud;
Manx: 14 As hooar Azor Sadoc, as hooar Sadoc Achim, as hooar Achim Eliud.

English: And Eliud begat Eleazar; and Eleazar begat Matthan; and Matthan begat Jacob;
Manx: 15 As hooar Eliud Eleazar, as hooar Eleazar Matthan, as hooar Matthan Jacob.

English: And Jacob begat Joseph the husband of Mary, of whom was born Jesus, who is called Christ.
Manx: 16 As hooar Jacob Joseph sheshey Moirrey, jee rugg Yeesey, ta enmyssit Creest.

English: So all the generations from Abraham to David are fourteen generations; and from David until the carrying away into Babylon are fourteen generations; and from the carrying away into Babylon unto Christ are fourteen generations.
Manx: 17 Myr shen ta ooilley ny sheeloghyn veih Abraham gys David, kiare sheeloghyn jeig: as veih David derrey’n chappeeys ayns Babylon, kiare sheeloghyn jeig: as veih’n chappeeys ayns Babylon derrey Creest, kiare sheeloghyn jeig.

English: Now the birth of Jesus Christ was on this wise: When as his mother Mary was espoused to Joseph, before they came together, she was found with child of the Holy Ghost.
Manx: 18 ¶ Nish va cheet er y theihll Yeesey Creest er yn aght shoh: Erreish da e voir Moirrey ve nasht rish Joseph, roish my daink ad dy vaghey cooidjagh, [A 2] va liannoo er ny gheddyn dy ve ayn-jee jeh’n Spyrryd Noo.

English: Then Joseph her husband, being a just man, and not willing to make her a publick example, was minded to put her away privily.
Manx: 19 As myr va Joseph e sheshey ny ghooinney cairagh, as liorish dy row Eh neu-wooiagh yn nearey eck y insh magh dy foshlit, ghow Eh ayns laue dy scarrey ree dy follit.

English: But while he thought on these things, behold, the angel of the Lord appeared unto him in a dream, saying, Joseph, thou son of David, fear not to take unto thee Mary thy wife: for that which is conceived in her is of the Holy Ghost.
Manx: 20 Agh choud as va ny reddyn shoh ayns e smooinaghtyn, cur-my-ner, haink ainle y Chiarn huggey ayns ashlish, gra, Yoseph vac Ghavid, ny gow aggle Moirrey yn ven ayd y ghoaill: son shen t’er ny yentyn ayn-jee, te jeh’n Spyrryd Noo.

English: And she shall bring forth a son, and thou shalt call his name Jesus: for he shall save his people from their sins.
Manx: 21 As ver ee mac son y theihll, as enmys-ee oo yn ennym echey Yeesey: son sauee Eh e phobble veih nyn beccaghyn.

English: Now all this was done, that it might be fulfilled which was spoken of the Lord by the prophet, saying,
Manx: 22 (Nish va ooilley shoh jeant, dy voddagh shen ve cooilleenit va’n Chiarn er loayrt liorish y phadeyr, gra,

English: Behold, a virgin shall be with child, and shall bring forth a son, and they shall call his name Emmanuel, which being interpreted is, God with us.
Manx: 23 Cur-my-ner, bee liannoo ec moidyn, as ver ee mac son y theihll, as nee ad Eh y enmys Emmanuel, ta shen dy ghra, Jee mârin).

English: Then Joseph being raised from sleep did as the angel of the Lord had bidden him, and took unto him his wife:
Manx: 24 Tra va Joseph eisht er n’irree veih cadley, ren Eh myr va ainle y Chiarn er n’oardaghey da, as ghow Eh thie e ven:

English: And knew her not till she had brought forth her firstborn son: and he called his name Jesus.
Manx: 25 As cha row veg echey dy yannoo ree, derrey hug ee e chied mac rugg jee son y theihll, as denmys eh yn ennym echey Yeesey.
CAB. II.

English: Now when Jesus was born in Bethlehem of Judaea in the days of Herod the king, behold, there came wise men from the east to Jerusalem,
Manx: Nish lurg da Yeesey er ve ruggitt ayns Bethlehem dy Yudea, ayns laghyn ree Herod, cur-my-ner, haink deiney creeney veih’n shar gys Jerusalem,

English: Saying, Where is he that is born King of the Jews? for we have seen his star in the east, and are come to worship him.
Manx: 2 Gra, Cre vel Ree ny Hewnyn t’er jeet er y theihll? son honnick shin y rollage echey ayns y shar, as ta shin er jeet dy chur ooashley da.

English: When Herod the king had heard these things, he was troubled, and all Jerusalem with him.
Manx: 3 Tra cheayll ree Herod shoh, ve seaghnit, as ooilley Jerusalem marish.

English: And when he had gathered all the chief priests and scribes of the people together, he demanded of them where Christ should be born.
Manx: 4 As tra v’eh er jaglym cooidjagh ooilley ny ard-saggyrtyn as scruderyn y pobble, dênee Eh jeu, cre’n raad va Creest dy heet er y theihll.

English: And they said unto him, In Bethlehem of Judaea: for thus it is written by the prophet,
Manx: 5 As dooyrt adsyn rish, Ayns Bethlehem dy Yudea: son shoh myr te scruit liorish y phadeyr;

English: And thou Bethlehem, in the land of Juda, art not the least among the princes of Juda: for out of thee shall come a Governor, that shall rule my people Israel.
Manx: 6 As uss Bethlehem ayns thalloo Yuda, cha nee oo sloo ta, mâstey prinsyn Yuda: son ass-yds hig Kiannoort nee reill my phobble Israel.

English: Then Herod, when he had privily called the wise men, enquired of them diligently what time the star appeared.
Manx: 7 Eisht hug Herod fys dy follit er ny deiney creeney, as vrie Eh jeu dy imneagh cre’n tra va’n rollage er ny akin.

English: And he sent them to Bethlehem, and said, Go and search diligently for the young child; and when ye have found him, bring me word again, that I may come and worship him also.
Manx: 8 As hug Eh ad gys Bethlehem, gra, Immee-jee, as shir-jee magh dy kiarralagh son y liannoo aeg, as tra vees shiu er gheddyn Eh, tar-jee lesh fys hym’s, dy voddym’s cheet as ooashley chur da myrgeddin.

English: When they had heard the king, they departed; and, lo, the star, which they saw in the east, went before them, till it came and stood over where the young child was.
Manx: 9 Tra va’n ree erreish loayrt, jimmee ad rymboo, as cur-my-ner, hie yn rollage honnick ad ayns y shar roue, derrey haink ee as hass ee harrish yn ynnyd raad va’n liannoo aeg.

English: When they saw the star, they rejoiced with exceeding great joy.
Manx: 10 Tra honnick ad y rollage, v’ad lhieent lesh boggey er-skyn towse.

English: And when they were come into the house, they saw the young child with Mary his mother, and fell down, and worshipped him: and when they had opened their treasures, they presented unto him gifts; gold, and frankincense and myrrh.
Manx: 11 ¶ As tra v’ad er jeet stiagh ayns y thie, honnick ad y liannoo aeg marish Moirrey e voir, as huit ad sheese, as hug ad ooashley da: as tra v’ad er vosley ny tashtaghyn oc, heb ad da giootyn; airh, as frankincense, as myrrh.

English: And being warned of God in a dream that they should not return to Herod, they departed into their own country another way.
Manx: 12 As fakin dy row Jee er chur roue ayns ashlish, nagh row ad dy hyndaa gys Herod, jimmee ad gys nyn jeer hene raad elley.

English: And when they were departed, behold, the angel of the Lord appeareth to Joseph in a dream, saying, Arise, and take the young child and his mother, and flee into Egypt, and be thou there until I bring thee word: for Herod will seek the young child to destroy him.
Manx: 13 As tra v’ad er gholl roue, cur-my-ner, haink ainle y Chiarn gys Joseph ayns ashlish, gra, Irree, as gow yn liannoo aeg as e voir, as gow er-chea gys Egypt, as fuirree ayns shen derrey verryms lhiam fys hood: son shirree Herod y liannoo aeg dy stroie Eh.

English: When he arose, he took the young child and his mother by night, and departed into Egypt:
Manx: 14 Tra v’eh er n’irree, ghow Eh yn liannoo aeg as e voir ayns yn oie, as hie Eh roish gys Egypt:

English: And was there until the death of Herod: that it might be fulfilled which was spoken of the Lord by the prophet, saying, Out of Egypt have I called my son.
Manx: 15 As v’eh ayns shen derrey baase Herod: dy voddagh shen ve cooilleenit va’n Chiarn er loayrt liorish y phadeyr, gra, Magh ass Egypt deïe mee er my vac.

English: Then Herod, when he saw that he was mocked of the wise men, was exceeding wroth, and sent forth, and slew all the children that were in Bethlehem, and in all the coasts thereof, from two years old and under, according to the time which he had diligently enquired of the wise men.
Manx: 16 ¶ Tra honnick Herod eisht dy row Eh mollit liorish ny deiney creeney, v’eh feer jymmoosagh, as hug Eh magh saarey, as varr Eh ooilley yn chloan v’ayns Bethlehem, as ayns ooilley ny ardjyn shen, veih daa vleïn dy eash as fo, cordail rish y traa v’eh dy imneagh er vriaght jeh ny deiney creeney.

English: Then was fulfilled that which was spoken by Jeremy the prophet, saying,
Manx: 17 Shen y traa va cooilleenit ny va loayrit liorish Jeremy yn phadeyr, gra,

English: In Rama was there a voice heard, lamentation, and weeping, and great mourning, Rachel weeping for her children, and would not be comforted, because they are not.
Manx: 18 Ayns Rama va coraa er ny chlashtyn, ullaghey as keaney, as dobberan mooar, Rachel keaney son e cloan, as gobbal dy ve er ny gherjaghey, er-yn-oyr nagh row ad er-mayrn.

English: But when Herod was dead, behold, an angel of the Lord appeareth in a dream to Joseph in Egypt,
Manx: 19 ¶ Agh tra va Herod marroo, cur-my-ner, haink ainle y Chiarn ayns ashlish gys Joseph ayns Egypt,

English: Saying, Arise, and take the young child and his mother, and go into the land of Israel: for they are dead which sought the young child's life.
Manx: 20 Gra, Irree, as gow yn liannoo aeg as e voir, as gow gys thalloo Israel: son t’adsyn marroo va shirrey bioys y liannoo.

English: And he arose, and took the young child and his mother, and came into the land of Israel.
Manx: 21 As dirree Eh, as ghow Eh yn liannoo as e voir, as haink Eh gys thalloo Israel.

English: But when he heard that Archelaus did reign in Judaea in the room of his father Herod, he was afraid to go thither: notwithstanding, being warned of God in a dream, he turned aside into the parts of Galilee:
Manx: 22 Agh tra cheayll Eh dy nee Archelaus va reill ayns Judea, ayns ynnyd e ayr Herod, va aggle er dy gholl ayns shen, agh hyndaa Eh, myr va Jee er chur roish ayns ashlish, gys ardjyn Ghalilee:

English: And he came and dwelt in a city called Nazareth: that it might be fulfilled which was spoken by the prophets, He shall be called a Nazarene.
Manx: 23 As haink Eh as ren Eh vaghey ayns ard-valley enmyssit Nazareth, dy voddagh ny va loayrit liorish ny phadeyryn ve cooilleenit, Bee Eh enmyssit ny Nazarene.
CAB. III.

English: In those days came John the Baptist, preaching in the wilderness of Judaea,
Manx: Ayns ny laghyn shen haink Ean Bashtey, preacheil ayns faasagh Yudea,

English: And saying, Repent ye: for the kingdom of heaven is at hand.
Manx: 2 As gra, Gow-jee arrys: son ta reeriaght niau er-gerrey.

English: For this is he that was spoken of by the prophet Esaias, saying, The voice of one crying in the wilderness, Prepare ye the way of the Lord, make his paths straight.
Manx: 3 Son shoh Eh va loayrit jeh liorish y phadeyr Esaias, gra, Coraa fer geamagh ayns yn aasagh, Jean-jee aarloo raad y Chiarn, jean-jee ny cassanyn echey kiart.

English: And the same John had his raiment of camel's hair, and a leathern girdle about his loins; and his meat was locusts and wild honey.
Manx: 4 As va ec Ean cheddin coamrey dy chlooie chamel, as cryss liare mysh ny meeghyn echey; as va e veaghey locustyn as mill feïe.

English: Then went out to him Jerusalem, and all Judaea, and all the region round about Jordan,
Manx: 5 Eisht hie magh huggey Jerusalem as ooilley Judea, as ooilley’n cheer mygeayrt Jordan,

English: And were baptized of him in Jordan, confessing their sins.
Manx: 6 As v’ad er nyn mashtey liorish ayns Jordan, goaill-rish nyn beccaghyn.

English: But when he saw many of the Pharisees and Sadducees come to his baptism, he said unto them, O generation of vipers, who hath warned you to flee from the wrath to come?
Manx: 7 ¶ Agh tra honnick Eh ymmodee jeh ny Phariseeyn as ny Sadduceeyn cheet gys e vashtey, dooyrt Eh roo, O heeloghe dy ard-nieughyn, quoi t’er chur raaue diu dy hea veih yn chorree ta ry heet?

English: Bring forth therefore fruits meet for repentance:
Manx: 8 Ymmyrk-jee magh er-y-fa shen messyn cooie dy arrys.

English: And think not to say within yourselves, We have Abraham to our father: for I say unto you, that God is able of these stones to raise up children unto Abraham.
Manx: 9 As ny smooinee-jee dy ghra cheu-sthie jiu hene, Ta Abraham ain son nyn ayr: son ta mee gra riu, dy vel Jee abyl jeh ny claghyn shoh, cloan y hroggal seose da Abraham.

English: And now also the axe is laid unto the root of the trees: therefore every tree which bringeth not forth good fruit is hewn down, and cast into the fire.
Manx: 10 As nish myrgeddin ta’n teigh er ny choyrt gys fraue ny miljyn: shen-y-fa ta dy chooilley villey nagh vel gymmyrkey magh mess mie, dy ve giarit sheese as tilgit ayns yn aile.

English: I indeed baptize you with water unto repentance: but he that cometh after me is mightier than I, whose shoes I am not worthy to bear: he shall baptize you with the Holy Ghost, and with fire:
Manx: 11 Ta mish dy jarroo bashtey shiu lesh ushtey gys arrys: agh ta eshyn ta cheet my yei, ny spooaral na mish, ny braagyn echey cha vel mee feeu dy ymmyrkey: bashtee eshyn shiu lesh y Spyrryd Noo as lesh aile.

English: Whose fan is in his hand, and he will throughly purge his floor, and gather his wheat into the garner; but he will burn up the chaff with unquenchable fire.
Manx: 12 Ta’n chleayst echey ayns e laue, as nee Eh dy bollagh e laare-arroo y ghlenney, as gowee Eh e churnaght stiagh ayns y thie-tashtee: agh loshtee Eh yn choau lesh aile nagh vod v’er ny vooghey.

English: Then cometh Jesus from Galilee to Jordan unto John, to be baptized of him.
Manx: 13 ¶ Eisht haink Yeesey veih Galilee gys Jordan gys Ean, dy ve er ny vashtey liorish.

English: But John forbad him, saying, I have need to be baptized of thee, and comest thou to me?
Manx: 14 Agh loayr Ean noi, gra, Ta feme ayms er ve bashtit liorts, as vel uss er-jeet hyms?

English: And Jesus answering said unto him, Suffer it to be so now: for thus it becometh us to fulfil all righteousness. Then he suffered him.
Manx: 15 Dreggyr Yeesey, as dooyrt Eh rish, Cur raad dou nish: son shoh myr te cooie dooin dy chooilley chairys y chooilleeney. Eisht lig Eh da.

English: 16 And Jesus, when he was baptized, went up straightway out of the water: and, lo, the heavens were opened unto him, and he saw the Spirit of God descending like a dove, and lighting upon him:
Manx: 16 As hie Yeesey, tra v’eh er ny vashtey, seose chelleeragh as yn ushtey: as cur-my-ner, va ny niaughyn er nyn vosley er e skyn, as honnick Eh Spyrryd Yee cheet neose myr calmane, as soie er.

English: 17 And lo a voice from heaven, saying, This is my beloved Son, in whom I am well pleased.
Manx: 17 As cur-my-ner, coraa veih niau, gra, Shoh my Vac graihagh, jeh ta mee dy mooar soiaghey.
CAB. IV.

English: Then was Jesus led up of the spirit into the wilderness to be tempted of the devil.
Manx: Eisht va Yeesey er ny leeideil liorish spyrryd Yee gys yn aasagh, dy v’er ny violaghey liorish y drogh-spyrryd.

English: And when he had fasted forty days and forty nights, he was afterward an hungred.
Manx: 2 As tra v’eh er drostey da-eed laa as da-eed oie v’eh ny lurg shen accryssagh.

English: And when the tempter came to him, he said, If thou be the Son of God, command that these stones be made bread.
Manx: 3 As haink y miolyder huggey, gra, My she Mac Yee oo, cur saarey da ny claghyn shoh dy ve jeant nyn arran.

English: But he answered and said, It is written, Man shall not live by bread alone, but by every word that proceedeth out of the mouth of God.
Manx: 4 Agh dreggyr eshyn, gra, Te scruit, Cha nee er arran ny lomarcan nee dooinney beaghey, agh liorish cre-erbee ta cheet magh ass beeal Yee.

English: Then the devil taketh him up into the holy city, and setteth him on a pinnacle of the temple,
Manx: 5 Eisht hug y drogh-spyrryd lesh Eh gys yn ard-valley casherick, as hoie Eh Eh er eer-vullagh y chiamble,

English: And saith unto him, If thou be the Son of God, cast thyself down: for it is written, He shall give his angels charge concerning thee: and in their hands they shall bear thee up, lest at any time thou dash thy foot against a stone.
Manx: 6 As dooyrt Eh rish, My she Mac Yee oo, tilg oo hene sheese: son te scruit, Ver Eh currym da e ainlyn my dty chione, as ayns nyn laueyn nee ad oo y ymmyrkey, er aggle ec traa erbee, dy bwoail oo dty chass noi clagh.

English: Jesus said unto him, It is written again, Thou shalt not tempt the Lord thy God.
Manx: 7 Dooyrt Yeesey rish, Te scruit reesht, Cha jean oo yn Chiarn dty Yee y violaghey.

English: Again, the devil taketh him up into an exceeding high mountain, and sheweth him all the kingdoms of the world, and the glory of them;
Manx: 8 Reesht hug y drogh-spyrryd lesh Eh seose er slieau feer ard, as yeeagh Eh da ooilley reeriaghtyn y theihll as y ghloyr oc:

English: And saith unto him, All these things will I give thee, if thou wilt fall down and worship me.
Manx: 9 As dooyrt Eh rish, Ooilley shoh verryms dhyt, my huittys oo sheese, as ooashley ’chur dou.

English: Then saith Jesus unto him, Get thee hence, Satan: for it is written, Thou shalt worship the Lord thy God, and him only shalt thou serve.
Manx: 10 Eisht dooyrt Yeesey rish, Gow ass my enish, Noid-anmey: son te scruit, Ver oo ooashley da’n Chiarn dty Yee, as eshyn ny lomarcan nee oo y hirveish.

English: Then the devil leaveth him, and, behold, angels came and ministered unto him.
Manx: 11 Eisht daag y drogh-spyrryd Eh, as cur-my-ner, haink ainlyn as ren ad Eh y hirveish.

English: Now when Jesus had heard that John was cast into prison, he departed into Galilee;
Manx: 12 ¶ Nish tra cheayll Yeesey dy row ad er ghoaill Ean, jimmee Eh roish gys Galilee.

English: And leaving Nazareth, he came and dwelt in Capernaum, which is upon the sea coast, in the borders of Zabulon and Nephthalim:
Manx: 13 As daag Eh Nazareth, as haink Eh dy vaghey ayns Capernaum, ta rish oirr ny marrey, ayns ardjyn Zabulon as Nephthalim:

English: That it might be fulfilled which was spoken by Esaias the prophet, saying,
Manx: 14 Dy voddagh ve cooilleenit ny va loayrit liorish Esaias yn phadeyr, gra,

English: The land of Zabulon, and the land of Nephthalim, by the way of the sea, beyond Jordan, Galilee of the Gentiles;
Manx: 15 Thalloo Zabulon, as thalloo Nephthalim, er slyst ny marrey, cheu elley dy Yordan, Galilee jeh ny Ashoonyn:

English: The people which sat in darkness saw great light; and to them which sat in the region and shadow of death light is sprung up.
Manx: 16 Ta’n pobble va nyn soie ayns dorraghys, er vakin soilshey mooar: as dauesyn va nyn soie ayns cheer as scadoo’n vaish, ta soilshey er n’irree seose.

English: From that time Jesus began to preach, and to say, Repent: for the kingdom of heaven is at hand.
Manx: 17 ¶ Veih’n traa shen ren Yeesey toshiaght dy phreacheil, as dy ghra, Gow-jee arrys, son ta reeriaght niau er-gerrey.

English: And Jesus, walking by the sea of Galilee, saw two brethren, Simon called Peter, and Andrew his brother, casting a net into the sea: for they were fishers.
Manx: 18 ¶ As honnick Yeesey, myr v’eh shooyl liorish keayn Ghalilee, da vraar, Simon, va enmyssit Peddyr, as Andreays e vraar, cur magh lieen ’sy cheayn: (son v’ad nyn Eeastairyn)

English: And he saith unto them, Follow me, and I will make you fishers of men.
Manx: 19 As dooyrt Eh roo, Eiyr-jee orryms, as nee’ms shiu nyn * Eeastairyn dy gheiney.
* Tayrnee shiu deiney gys Jee.

English: And they straightway left their nets, and followed him.
Manx: 20 As chelleeragh daag ad nyn lieenteenyn, as deiyr ad er.

English: And going on from thence, he saw other two brethren, James the son of Zebedee, and John his brother, in a ship with Zebedee their father, mending their nets; and he called them.
Manx: 21 As tra v’eh er gholl veih shen, honnick Eh daa vraar elley, Jamys mac Zebedee, as Ean e vraar, ayns lhong marish Zebedee nyn ayr, karraghey ny lieenteenyn oc: as deïe Eh orroo.

English: And they immediately left the ship and their father, and followed him.
Manx: 22 As daag ad chelleeragh y lhong as nyn ayr, as deiyr ad er.

English: And Jesus went about all Galilee, teaching in their synagogues, and preaching the gospel of the kingdom, and healing all manner of sickness and all manner of disease among the people.
Manx: 23 ¶ As hie Yeesey mygeayrt ooilley Galilee, gynsaghey ayns ny kialteenyn oc, as preacheil sushtal y reeriaght, as lheihys dy chooilley hingys, as dy chooilley ghoghan mastey’n pobble.

English: And his fame went throughout all Syria: and they brought unto him all sick people that were taken with divers diseases and torments, and those which were possessed with devils, and those which were lunatick, and those that had the palsy; and he healed them.
Manx: 24 As hie yn ennym echey magh trooid ooilley Syria: as hug ad lhieu huggey ooilley adsyn va fo aslaïntyn, adsyn va fo caghlaaghyn dy ghoghanyn as dy gheiaghyn, adsyn va drogh-spyrrydyn ayndoo, yn vooinjer va eddrym ayns nyn geeal rish caghlaa ny haist, as adsyn va’n chingys-cra orroo, as ren Eh ad y lheihys.

English: And there followed him great multitudes of people from Galilee, and from Decapolis, and from Jerusalem, and from Judaea, and from beyond Jordan.
Manx: 25 As deiyr er chaglym mooar dy leih, veih Galilee, as Decapolis, as Jerusalem, as Judea, as veih cheu elley dy Yordan.
CAB. V.

English: And seeing the multitudes, he went up into a mountain: and when he was set, his disciples came unto him:
Manx: As fakin leid ny earrooyn dy leih, hie Eh seose er slieau: as tra v’eh er hoie sheese, haink huggey yn vooinjer va sheer geiyrt er.

English: And he opened his mouth, and taught them, saying,
Manx: 2 As doshil Eh e veeal, as dynsee Eh ad, gra,

English: Blessed are the poor in spirit: for theirs is the kingdom of heaven.
Manx: 3 Bannit t’adsyn ta boght ayns spyrryd: son lhieusyn reeriaght niau.

English: Blessed are they that mourn: for they shall be comforted.
Manx: 4 Bannit t’adsyn ta jannoo dobberan: son bee ad er nyn gherjaghey.

English: Blessed are the meek: for they shall inherit the earth.
Manx: 5 Bannit t’adsyn ta imlee: son bee yn thalloo oc ayns eiraght.

English: Blessed are they which do hunger and thirst after righteousness: for they shall be filled.
Manx: 6 Bannit t’adsyn † ta accryssagh as pa-agh lurg cairys: son bee ad er nyn yannoo magh.
† Ta dy jeean shirrey lurg cairys.

English: Blessed are the merciful: for they shall obtain mercy.
Manx: 7 Bannit ta’n vooinjer vyghinagh: son bee myghin er ny hoilshaghey daue.

English: Blessed are the pure in heart: for they shall see God.
Manx: 8 Bannit t’adsyn ta glen ayns cree: son nee ad Jee y akin.

English: Blessed are the peacemakers: for they shall be called the children of God.
Manx: 9 Bannit t’adsyn ta tayrn sleih gys shee: son bee ad enmyssit nyn gloan dy Yee.

English: Blessed are they which are persecuted for righteousness’ sake: for theirs is the kingdom of heaven.
Manx: 10 Bannit t’adsyn ta surranse tranlaase er graih cairys: son lhieusyn reeriaght niau.

English: Blessed are ye, when men shall revile you, and persecute you, and shall say all manner of evil against you falsely, for my sake.
Manx: 11 Bannit ta shiuish tra vees shiu oltooanit, as tranlaasit, as dy chooilley ghrogh red er ny ghra nyn oi dy breagagh er y choontey ayms.

English: Rejoice, and be exceeding glad: for great is your reward in heaven: for so persecuted they the prophets which were before you.
Manx: 12 Gow-jee boggey, as bee-jee feer wooiagh; son mooar ta’n leagh eu ayns niau: son shoh myr ren ad tranlaase er ny phadeyryn va rymbiu.

English: Ye are the salt of the earth: but if the salt have lost his savour, wherewith shall it be salted? it is thenceforth good for nothing, but to be cast out, and to be trodden under foot of men.
Manx: 13 ¶ Shiuish sollan y thalloo: agh my ta’n sollan er choall e vlass, kys hig e vree ayn reesht? cha vel ymmyd erbee sodjey ny chouyr, agh dy ve tilgit magh as stampit fo cassyn deiney.

English: Ye are the light of the world. A city that is set on an hill cannot be hid.
Manx: 14 Shiuish soilshey’n theihll. Cha vod ard-valley ta soit er cronck ve follit.

English: Neither do men light a candle, and put it under a bushel, but on a candlestick; and it giveth light unto all that are in the house.
Manx: 15 Cha-moo ta sleih foddey kainle, as dy choyrt ee fo saagh; agh ayns kainlere, as ti-ee cur soilshey da ooilley ny t’ayns y thie.

English: Let your light so shine before men, that they may see your good works, and glorify your Father which is in heaven.
Manx: 16 Lig da’n soilshey eauish myr shen soilshean kiongoyrt rish deiney, dy vod ad fakin ny obbraghyn mie eu, as gloyr y choyrt da nyn ayr t’ayns niau.

English: Think not that I am come to destroy the law, or the prophets: I am not come to destroy, but to fulfil.
Manx: 17 ¶ Ny smooinee-jee dy daink mish dy chur mou yn leigh as ny phadeyryn: cha nee dy chur mou haink mee, agh dy lhieeney.

English: For verily I say unto you, Till heaven and earth pass, one jot or one tittle shall in no wise pass from the law, till all be fulfilled.
Manx: 18 Son dy firrinagh ta mee gra riu, Derrey nee aer as thalloo cherraghtyn, cha bee un ockle ny un tittle er ny ghoaill veih’n leigh, derrey vees ooilley jeant magh.

English: Whosoever therefore shall break one of these least commandments, and shall teach men so, he shall be called the least in the kingdom of heaven: but whosoever shall do and teach them, the same shall be called great in the kingdom of heaven.
Manx: 19 Quoi-erbee er-y-fa shen vrishys annane jeh ny saaraghyn sloo shoh, as ynsys deiney myr shen, bee Eh enmyssit yn fer sloo ayns reeriaght niau: agh quoi-erbee nee nyn yannoo as nyn ynsaghey ad, bee Eh enmyssit mooar ayns reeriaght niau.

English: For I say unto you, That except your righteousness shall exceed the righteousness of the scribes and Pharisees, ye shall in no case enter into the kingdom of heaven.
Manx: 20 Son ta mee gra riu, Mannagh bee yn ynrycys eauish er-skyn ynrycys ny scruderyn as ny Phariseeyn, nagh vod shiu er aght erbee goll stiagh ayns reeriaght niau.

English: Ye have heard that it was said of them of old time, Thou shalt not kill; and whosoever shall kill shall be in danger of the judgment:
Manx: 21 ¶ Ta shiu er chlashtyn dy row eh er ny ghra roosyn jeh’n chen earish, Cha jean oo dunverys: as quoi-erbee nee dunverys, toillee Eh kerraghey’n vriwnys.

English: But I say unto you, That whosoever is angry with his brother without a cause shall be in danger of the judgment: and whosoever shall say to his brother, Raca, shall be in danger of the council: but whosoever shall say, Thou fool, shall be in danger of hell fire.
Manx: 22 Agh ta mish gra riuish, quoi-erbee ta corree rish e vraar fegooish oyr, dy doill Eh dy ve deyrit liorish y vriwnys: as quoi erbee jir rish e vraar, Raca, dy doill Eh v’er ny gheyrey liorish y choonceil: agh quoi-erbbee jir, Uss ommydan, dy doill Eh deyrey gys aile niurin.

English: Therefore if thou bring thy gift to the altar, and there rememberest that thy brother hath ought against thee;
Manx: 23 Shen-y-fa tra vees oo chebbal dty yioot er yn altar, my chooinys oo ayns shen dy vel nhee erbee ec dty vraar dt’oi;

English: Leave there thy gift before the altar, and go thy way; first be reconciled to thy brother, and then come and offer thy gift.
Manx: 24 Faag ayns shen dty yioot kiongoyrt rish yn altar, as immee royd, tayrn hoshiaght dty vraar gys shee, as eisht tar as cheb dty yioot.

English: Agree with thine adversary quickly, whiles thou art in the way with him; lest at any time the adversary deliver thee to the judge, and the judge deliver thee to the officer, and thou be cast into prison.
Manx: 25 Cord dy tappee rishyn ta streeu rhyt, choud as vees shiu goll cooidjagh er y raad: er aggle dy livrey Eh oo seose gys y vriw, as dy livrey yn briw oo huggeysyn ta goaill kerraghey, as dy bee oo tilgit ayns pryssoon.

English: Verily I say unto thee, Thou shalt by no means come out thence, till thou hast paid the uttermost farthing.
Manx: 26 Dy firrinagh ta mee gra rhyt, Nagh jig oo magh ass shen, derrey vees oo erreish yn farling sodjey magh y eeck.

English: Ye have heard that it was said by them of old time, Thou shalt not commit adultery:
Manx: 27 ¶ Ta shiu er chlashtyn dy row eh er ny ghra roosyn jeh’n chen earish, Cha brish oo poosey.

English: But I say unto you, That whosoever looketh on a woman to lust after her hath committed adultery with her already in his heart.
Manx: 28 Agh ta mish gra riu, quoi-erbee ta jeeaghyn er ben dy chur saynt jee, dy vel Eh er vrishey poosey ree hannah ayns e chree.

English: And if thy right eye offend thee, pluck it out, and cast it from thee: for it is profitable for thee that one of thy members should perish, and not that thy whole body should be cast into hell.
Manx: 29 As my ta dty hooyl yesh dy dty hayrn gys peccah, pluck assyd ee, as tilg woid ee: son te ny share dhyt annane jeh dty hooyllyn y choall, ny dty slane corp dy ve tilgit ayns niurin.

English: And if thy right hand offend thee, cut it off, and cast it from thee: for it is profitable for thee that one of thy members should perish, and not that thy whole body should be cast into hell.
Manx: 30 As my vees dty laue yesh dy dty hayrn gys peccah, giare jeed as tilg woid ee: son te ny share dhyt annane jeh dty oltyn y choall, ny dty slane corp dy ve tilgit ayns niurin.

English: It hath been said, Whosoever shall put away his wife, let him give her a writing of divorcement:
Manx: 31 Ve er ny ghra, Quoi-erbee ver e ven woish, lig da screeuyn-scarree y chur jee.

English: But I say unto you, That whosoever shall put away his wife, saving for the cause of fornication, causeth her to commit adultery: and whosoever shall marry her that is divorced committeth adultery.
Manx: 32 Agh ta mish gra riu, quoi-erbee scarrys rish e ven, cheu-moie jeh son oyr maarderys, dy vel Eh cur urree poosey vrishey: as quoi-erbee phoosys ish ta scart, t’eh brishey poosey.

English: Again, ye have heard that it hath been said by them of old time, Thou shalt not forswear thyself, but shalt perform unto the Lord thine oaths:
Manx: 33 ¶ Myrgeddin, ta shiu er chlashtyn dy row eh er ny ghra roosyn jeh’n chen earish, Cha jean oo loo oi-agh y ghoaill, agh cooilleenee oo ny t’ow dy loo gys y Chiarn.

English: But I say unto you, Swear not at all; neither by heaven; for it is God's throne:
Manx: 34 Agh ta mish gra riu, Ny loo-jee er aght erbee; edyr liorish niau, son she stoyl-reeoil Yee eh:

English: Nor by the earth; for it is his footstool: neither by Jerusalem; for it is the city of the great King.
Manx: 35 Ny liorish y thalloo, son shen y stoyl ta fo e chassyn: ny liorish Jerusalem, son shen ard-valley’n Ree mooar.

English: Neither shalt thou swear by thy head, because thou canst not make one hair white or black.
Manx: 36 Cha-moo loo-ys oo liorish dty chione, er-yn-oyr nagh vod oo un renaig y yannoo bane ny doo.

English: But let your communication be, Yea, yea; Nay, nay: for whatsoever is more than these cometh of evil.
Manx: 37 Agh lig da’n ghlare eu ve, She, she; Cha nee, cha nee: son cre-erbee ta er-skyn shoh, she jeh’n olk te cheet.

English: Ye have heard that it hath been said, An eye for an eye, and a tooth for a tooth:
Manx: 38 ¶ Ta shiu er chlashtyn dy row eh er ny ghra, Sooyl son sooyl, as feeackle son feeackle.

English: But I say unto you, That ye resist not evil: but whosoever shall smite thee on thy right cheek, turn to him the other also.
Manx: 39 Agh ta mish gra riu, Ny shir-jee aggair y chooilleeney: agh quoi-erbee woaillys oo er y lieckan yesh, chyndaa huggey yn lieckan elley.

English: And if any man will sue thee at the law, and take away thy coat, let him have thy cloak also.
Manx: 40 As my ta fer erbee dy dty chuirr ec y leigh, as goaill ersooyl dty chooat, lig dty chloagey lesh myrgeddin.

English: And whosoever shall compel thee to go a mile, go with him twain.
Manx: 41 As quoi-erbee ver lesh oo er niart un veeley, gow marish jees.

English: Give to him that asketh thee, and from him that would borrow of thee turn not thou away.
Manx: 42 Cur dasyn ta jannoo aghin hood, as veihsyn ta shirrey geeasaght woid, ny chyndaa ersooyl.

English: Ye have heard that it hath been said, Thou shalt love thy neighbour, and hate thine enemy.
Manx: 43 ¶ Ta shiu er chlashtyn dy row eh er ny ghra, Ver oo graih da dty naboo as feoh da dty noid:

English: But I say unto you, Love your enemies, bless them that curse you, do good to them that hate you, and pray for them which despitefully use you, and persecute you;
Manx: 44 Agh ta mish gra riu, Bee-jee graihagh er nyn noidjyn, bannee-jee adsyn ta guee mollaght diu, jean-jee mie dauesyn ta cur feoh diu, as gow-jee padjer er nyn son ocsyn ta cur seaghyn as jannoo tranlaase erriu:

English: That ye may be the children of your Father which is in heaven: for he maketh his sun to rise on the evil and on the good, and sendeth rain on the just and on the unjust.
Manx: 45 Dy vod shiu ve nyn gloan da’n Ayr eu t’ayns niau, son t’eshyn cur er e ghrian girree er olk as er mie, as cur fliaghey neose er y vooinjer chairagh as neu-chairagh.

English: For if ye love them which love you, what reward have ye? do not even the publicans the same?
Manx: 46 Son my ta shiu soilshaghey graih dauesyn ta graihagh erriuish, cre’n leagh ta nyn gouyr? nagh nee shoh myr ta ny eer publicanee jannoo?

English: And if ye salute your brethren only, what do ye more than others? do not even the publicans so?
Manx: 47 My she rish nyn mraaraghyn ny lomarcan ta shiu loayrt dy dooie, cre smoo ta shiu dy yannoo na feallagh elley? nagh vel ny eer publicanee jannoo myr shen?

English: Be ye therefore perfect, even as your Father which is in heaven is perfect.
Manx: 48 Bee-jee shiuish er-y-fa shen dy firrinagh mie, myr ta’n Ayr eu t’ayns niau laane dy oays firrinagh.
CAB. VI.

English: Take heed that ye do not your alms before men, to be seen of them: otherwise ye have no reward of your Father which is in heaven.
Manx: Cur-jee twoaie nagh der shiu da ny boghtyn kiongoyrt rish deiney, er coontey dy ve er ny akin lioroo: er nonney cha vow shiu leagh veih’n Ayr eu t’ayns niau.

English: Therefore when thou doest thine alms, do not sound a trumpet before thee, as the hypocrites do in the synagogues and in the streets, that they may have glory of men. Verily I say unto you, They have their reward.
Manx: 2 Shen-y-fa tra t’ow coyrt da ny boghtyn, ny lig da cayrn v’er ny heidey royd, lurg aght ny crauee-oalsey, ayn ny kialteenyn, as ayns ny straadjyn, er coontey moylley ’gheddyn veih deiney. Dy firrinagh ta mee gra riu, ta nyn leagh oc.

English: But when thou doest alms, let not thy left hand know what thy right hand doeth:
Manx: 3 Agh tra t’ow uss cur da ny boghtyn, ny lig da fys y ve ec dty laue chiare cre ta dty laue yesh dy yannoo:

English: That thine alms may be in secret: and thy Father which seeth in secret himself shall reward thee openly.
Manx: 4 Dy vod dty yeirk v’er ny choyrt dy follit: as nee dty Ayr ta fakin ny ta jeant dy follit, dty leagh y chur dhyt dy foshlit.

English: And when thou prayest, thou shalt not be as the hypocrites are: for they love to pray standing in the synagogues and in the corners of the streets, that they may be seen of men. Verily I say unto you, They have their reward.
Manx: 5 ¶ As tra vees oo goaill padjer, cha bee oo myr ny crauee-oalsey: son shynney lhieusyn shassoo seose ayns ny kialteenyn, as ayns corneilyn ny straadjyn dy ghoaill padjer, er chee dy v’er ny akin liorish deiney. Dy firrinagh ta mee gra riu, dy vel ad er gheddyn nyn leagh.

English: But thou, when thou prayest, enter into thy closet, and when thou hast shut thy door, pray to thy Father which is in secret; and thy Father which seeth in secret shall reward thee openly.
Manx: 6 Agh gow uss, tra vees oo goaill padjer, stiagh ayns dty hiamyr, as erreish dhyt dty ghorrys y yeigh, guee gys dty Ayr dy follit, as nee dty Ayr ta fakin ny ta jeant dy follit, leagh y chur dhyt dy foshlit.

English: But when ye pray, use not vain repetitions, as the heathen do: for they think that they shall be heard for their much speaking.
Manx: 7 Ny-yeih tra vees shiu guee, ny gow-jee rouyr taggloo erriu, goll-rish ny ashoonyn-quaagh: son t’adsyn goaill ayns laue dy vow ad nyn aghinyn liorish nyn ymmodee goan fardalagh.

English: Be not ye therefore like unto them: for your Father knoweth what things ye have need of, before ye ask him.
Manx: 8 Ny eiyr-jee shiuish er-y-fa shen er yn aght ocsyn: son ta fys ec nyn Ayr vre ta ymmyrchagh diu, roish my jean shiu aghin huggey.

English: After this manner therefore pray ye: Our Father which art in heaven, Hallowed be thy name.
Manx: 9 Er yn aght shoh er-y-fa shen gow-jee padjer: Ayr ain t’ayns niau, Casherick dy row dt’ennym.

English: Thy kingdom come, Thy will be done in earth, as it is in heaven.
Manx: 10 Dy jig dty reeriaght. Dt’aigney dy row jeant er y thalloo, myr te ayns niau.

English: Give us this day our daily bread.
Manx: 11 Cur dooin nyn arran jiu as gagh laa.

English: And forgive us our debts, as we forgive our debtors.
Manx: 12 As leih dooin nyn loghtyn, myr ta shin leih dauesyn ta jannoo loghtyn nyn oi.

English: And lead us not into temptation, but deliver us from evil: For thine is the kingdom, and the power, and the glory, for ever. Amen.
Manx: 13 As ny leeid shin ayns miolagh, agh livrey shin veih olk: Son lhiats y reeriaght, as y phooar, as y ghloyr, son dy bragh. Amen.

English: For if ye forgive men their trespasses, your heavenly Father will also forgive you:
Manx: 14 Son my leihys shiuish da deiney nyn loghtyn, leihee nyn Ayr flaunyssagh myrgeddin diuish.

English: But if ye forgive not men their trespasses, neither will your Father forgive your trespasses.
Manx: 15 Agh mannagh leih shiuish da deiney nyn voiljyn, cha jean yn Ayr eu nyn voiljyn y leih diuish.

English: Moreover when ye fast, be not, as the hypocrites, of a sad countenance: for they disfigure their faces, that they may appear unto men to fast. Verily I say unto you, They have their reward.
Manx: 16 ¶ As tra vees shiu trostey, ny bee-jee jeeaghyn trimshagh myr ny crauee-oalsey, son t’adsyn sollaghey nyn eddinyn er chee deiney dy chur tastey da’n trostey oc. Dy firrinagh ta mee gra riu, dy vel nyn leagh oc.

English: But thou, when thou fastest, anoint thine head, and wash thy face;
Manx: 17 Agh jean uss, tra vees oo trostey, dty chione y ooillaghey, as dt’eddin y oonlaghey:

English: That thou appear not unto men to fast, but unto thy Father which is in secret: and thy Father, which seeth in secret, shall reward thee openly.
Manx: 18 Er coontey nagh nee deiney ver tastey da’n trostey ayd, agh dty Ayr ta toiggal folliaghtyn: as nee dty Ayr ta fakin ny ta dy follit, leagh y chur dhyt dy foshlit.

English: Lay not up for yourselves treasures upon earth, where moth and rust doth corrupt, and where thieves break through and steal:
Manx: 19 ¶ Ny stoyr-jee seose berchys er nyn son eu hene er y thalloo, raad ta’n lhemeen as y mergey cur mow, as raad ta maarlee brishey stiagh as geid.

English: But lay up for yourselves treasures in heaven, where neither moth nor rust doth corrupt, and where thieves do not break through nor steal:
Manx: 20 Agh stoyr-jee er nyn son hene berchys ayns niau; raad nagh vel y lhemeen ny’n mergey cur mow, as raad nagh vel maarlee brishey stiagh as geid.

English: For where your treasure is, there will your heart be also.
Manx: 21 Son raad vees nyn stoyr, ayns shen vees y cree eu myrgeddin.

English: The light of the body is the eye: if therefore thine eye be single, thy whole body shall be full of light.
Manx: 22 Yn tooyl ta cur soilshey da’n chorp: shen-y-fa my ta’n tooyl fegooish foill, bee soilshey ec ooilley dty chorp.

English: But if thine eye be evil, thy whole body shall be full of darkness. If therefore the light that is in thee be darkness, how great is that darkness
Manx: 23 Agh my ta foill ayns dty hooyl, bee dty slane corp ayns dorraghys. My she dorraghys eisht yn soilshey ta aynyd, nagh mooar y dorraghys eh!

English: No man can serve two masters: for either he will hate the one, and love the other; or else he will hold to the one, and despise the other. Ye cannot serve God and mammon.
Manx: 24 ¶ Cha vod dooinney erbee daa vainshtyr y hirveish: son edyr ver Eh dwoaie da’n derrey yeh, as graih da’n jeh elley; ny bee Eh jeidjagh da’n derrey yeh, as soi-ee Eh beg jeh’n jeh elley. Cha vod shiu Jee as Mammon y hirveish.

English: Therefore I say unto you, Take no thought for your life, what ye shall eat, or what ye shall drink; nor yet for your body, what ye shall put on. Is not the life more than meat, and the body than raiment?
Manx: 25 Er-yn-oyr shoh ta mee gra riu, ny bee-jee imneagh son nyn mea, cre nee shiu y ee, ny cree [sic: cre] nee shiu y iu; ny foast son nyn girp cre ver shiu miu: Nagh vel y vea ny smoo dy ve soit jeh na beaghey, as y corp na coamrey?

English: Behold the fowls of the air: for they sow not, neither do they reap, nor gather into barns; yet your heavenly Father feedeth them. Are ye not much better than they?
Manx: 26 Cur-jee tastey da eeanlee’n aer: son cha vel ad cuirr ny buinn, ny chymsaghey stiagh ayns soaltyn; foast ta nyn Ayr flaunyssagh dyn meaghey ad. Nagh vel shiuish foddey share na adsyn?

English: Which of you by taking thought can add one cubit unto his stature?
Manx: 27 Quoi eauish liorish ve imneagh, oddys yn chraue-roih y chur gys yn aase echey?

English: And why take ye thought for raiment? Consider the lilies of the field, how they grow; they toil not, neither do they spin:
Manx: 28 As cre’n-fa ta shiu imneagh son coamraghyn? Gow-jee eu hene kys ta lilleeyn y vagher gaase; cha vel ad laboraght ny sneeu.

English: And yet I say unto you, That even Solomon in all his glory was not arrayed like one of these.
Manx: 29 As foast ta mee gra riu, nagh row Solomon hene ayns ooilley e ghloyr er ny choamrey myr annane jeu shoh.

English: Wherefore, if God so clothe the grass of the field, which to day is, and to morrow is cast into the oven, shall he not much more clothe you, O ye of little faith?
Manx: 30 My ta Jee er-y-fa shen myr shoh coamrey’n faiyr, ta jiu ’sy vagher, as mairagh ceaut stiagh ayns yn oghe, nagh jean Eh foddey smoo er nyn son eauish, O gheiney faase-chredjuagh?

English: Therefore take no thought, saying, What shall we eat? or, What shall we drink? or, Wherewithal shall we be clothed?
Manx: 31 Ny bee-jee er-y-fa shen imneagh, gra, Cre nee mad y ee? ny cree [sic: cre] nee mad y iu? ny cre yiow mad dy chur mooin?

English: (For after all these things do the Gentiles seek:) for your heavenly Father knoweth that ye have need of all these things.
Manx: 32 (Son ooilley ny reddyn shoh ta ny Ashoonyn-quaagh imneagh er nyn son) agh ec yn Ayr flaunyssagh eauish ta fys, dy vel feme eu er dy chooilley nhee jeu shoh.

English: But seek ye first the kingdom of God, and his righteousness; and all these things shall be added unto you.
Manx: 33 Agh shir-jee hoshiaght reeriaght Yee as e chairys, as bee shiu jeant magh lesh ooilley ny reddyn shoh.

English: Take therefore no thought for the morrow: for the morrow shall take thought for the things of itself. Sufficient unto the day is the evil thereof.
Manx: 34 Ny bee-jee er-y-fa shen ayns imnea erbee son y laa mairagh; son tra hig y laa mairagh hig e chiarrail marish: ta e heaghyn hene dy liooar er son y traa t’ayn.
CAB. VII.

English: Judge not, that ye be not judged.
Manx: Ny briwnys-jee, as cha bee shiu er nyn mriwnys.

English: For with what judgment ye judge, ye shall be judged: and with what measure ye mete, it shall be measured to you again.
Manx: 2 Son lesh y vriwnys ta shiu briwnys, bee shiu hene er nyn mriwnys; as lesh y towse ta shiu towse, bee eh er ny howse diu reesht.

English: And why beholdest thou the mote that is in thy brother's eye, but considerest not the beam that is in thine own eye?
Manx: 3 As cre’n-fa t’ow cronnaghey yn brenneein t’ayns sooyl dty vraar, agh cha vel oo smooinaghtyn er y beam t’ayns dty hooyl hene?

English: Or how wilt thou say to thy brother, Let me pull out the mote out of thine eye; and, behold, a beam is in thine own eye?
Manx: 4 Ny kys jir oo rish dty vraar, Lig dou yn brenneein y ghoaill ass dty hooyl, as cur-my-ner ta beam ayns dty hooyl hene?

English: Thou hypocrite, first cast out the beam out of thine own eye; and then shalt thou see clearly to cast out the mote out of thy brother's eye.
Manx: 5 Er-crauee-oalsey, tilg hoshiaght yn beam ass dty hooyl hene; as eisht bee soilshey ayd dy ghoaill yn brenneein ass sooyl dty vraarey.

English: Give not that which is holy unto the dogs, neither cast ye your pearls before swine, lest they trample them under their feet, and turn again and rend you.
Manx: 6 ¶ Ny cur-jee ny ta casherick da ny moddee, cha-moo hilgys shiu ny pearlyn eu roish muckyn, er aggle dy stamp ad ad fo nyn gassyn, as dy jyndaa ad reesht as dy lott ad shiu.

English: Ask, and it shall be given you; seek, and ye shall find; knock, and it shall be opened unto you:
Manx: 7 ¶ Yeearree-jee, as yiow shiu: shir-jee as nee shiu feddyn: bee-jee aignagh fosley gheddyn, as bee eh er ny osley diu.

English: For every one that asketh receiveth; and he that seeketh findeth; and to him that knocketh it shall be opened.
Manx: 8 Son ta dy chooilley annane ta geearree, geddyn: as y fer ta shirrey, feddyn: as eshyn ta aignagh fosley gheddyn, bee eh er ny osley da.

English: Or what man is there of you, whom if his son ask bread, will he give him a stone?
Manx: 9 Ny quoi’n dooinney nyn mast’ eauish, ver clagh da e vac, my hirrys Eh arran?

English: Or if he ask a fish, will he give him a serpent?
Manx: 10 Ny my hirrys Eh eeast, der Eh ard-nieu da?

English: If ye then, being evil, know how to give good gifts unto your children, how much more shall your Father which is in heaven give good things to them that ask him?
Manx: 11 My ta toiggal er-y-fa shen eauish ta olk, kys dy choyrt giootyn mie da nyn gloan, cre woad smoo nee’n Ayr eu t’ayns niau reddyn mie y choyrt dauesyn ta jannoo aghin huggey?

English: Therefore all things whatsoever ye would that men should do to you, do ye even so to them: for this is the law and the prophets.
Manx: 12 Shen-y-fa dy chooilley nhee cre-erbee balliuish deiney dy yannoo riuish, jean-jee shiuish myr shen roosyn: son shoh yn leigh as ny phadeyryn.

English: Enter ye in at the strait gate: for wide is the gate, and broad is the way, that leadeth to destruction, and many there be which go in thereat:
Manx: 13 ¶ Gow-jee stiagh er y yiat coon; son liane ta’n giat, as mooar ta’n raad ta leeideil gys tortmow, as shimmey ta goll er:

English: Because strait is the gate, and narrow is the way, which leadeth unto life, and few there be that find it.
Manx: 14 Er-y-fa dy nee chion ta’n giat, as coon ta’n raad ta leeideil gys bea, as schiark ta dy gheddyn magh eh.

English: Beware of false prophets, which come to you in sheep's clothing, but inwardly they are ravening wolves.
Manx: 15 ¶ Cur-jee twoaie jeh phadeyryn foalsey, ta cheet hiu ayns coamraghyn keayragh, agh cheu-sthie t’ad nyn moddee-oaldey jollyssagh.

English: Ye shall know them by their fruits. Do men gather grapes of thorns, or figs of thistles?
Manx: 16 Ver shiu enney orroo liorish nyn mess: Vel mess y villey-feeney er ny heiy jeh drinyn, ny mess y villey figgagh jeh onnanyn?

English: Even so every good tree bringeth forth good fruit; but a corrupt tree bringeth forth evil fruit.
Manx: 17 Myr shen ta dagh billey mie tilgey mess mie: agh ta drogh villey tilgey drogh vess.

English: A good tree cannot bring forth evil fruit, neither can a corrupt tree bring forth good fruit.
Manx: 18 Cha vod billey mie drogh vess y chur magh: ny drogh villey mess mie.

English: Every tree that bringeth not forth good fruit is hewn down, and cast into the fire.
Manx: 19 Ta dy chooilley villey nagh vel gymmyrkey magh mess mie, dy ve giarit sheese, as tilgit ayns yn aile.

English: Wherefore by their fruits ye shall know them.
Manx: 20 Shen-y-fa liorish nyn mess ver shiu enney orroo.

English: Not every one that saith unto me, Lord, Lord, shall enter into the kingdom of heaven; but he that doeth the will of my Father which is in heaven.
Manx: 21 ¶ Cha nee dy chooilley annane jir rhyms, Hiarn, Hiarn, hed stiagh ayns reeriaght niau: agh eshyn ta jannoo aigney m’ Ayrey t’ayns niau.

English: Many will say to me in that day, Lord, Lord, have we not prophesied in thy name? and in thy name have cast out devils? and in thy name done many wonderful works?
Manx: 22 Jir ymmodee rhyms ’sy laa shen, Hiarn, Hiarn, nagh vel shin er n’yannoo phadeyrys ayns dt’ennyms? as ayns dt’ennym er hilgey magh drogh-spyrrydyn? as ayns dt’ennym er n’yannoo ymmodee obbraghyn yindyssagh?

English: And then will I profess unto them, I never knew you: depart from me, ye that work iniquity.
Manx: 23 As eisht focklyms magh daue, Cha ren mee rieau goaill riu: immee-jee voym, ghrogh yantee.

English: Therefore whosoever heareth these sayings of mine, and doeth them, I will liken him unto a wise man, which built his house upon a rock:
Manx: 24 ¶ Quoi-erbee er-y-fa shen ta clashtyn ad shoh my ghoan’s, as ta jannoo ymmyd mie jeu, soyllee-ym Eh gys dooinney creeney hrog e hie er creg:

English: And the rain descended, and the floods came, and the winds blew, and beat upon that house; and it fell not: for it was founded upon a rock.
Manx: 25 As haink y fliaghey neose, as dhatt ny thooillaghyn, as heid ny geayghyn, as cheau ad er y thie shen: as cha huitt eh, son dy row yn undin echey er creg.

English: And every one that heareth these sayings of mine, and doeth them not, shall be likened unto a foolish man, which built his house upon the sand:
Manx: 26 As bee dy chooilley annane ta clashtyn ad shoh my ghoan’s, as nagh vel jannoo ymmyd mie jeu, er ny hoyllaghey gys dooinney ommijagh, hrog e hie er y gheinnagh:

English: And the rain descended, and the floods came, and the winds blew, and beat upon that house; and it fell: and great was the fall of it.
Manx: 27 As huitt y fliaghey, as dhatt ny thooillaghyn, as heid ny geayghyn, as cheau ad er y thie shen: as huitt eh, as mooar va’n toyrtmow echey.

English: And it came to pass, when Jesus had ended these sayings, the people were astonished at his doctrine:
Manx: 28 As haink eh gy kione tra va Yeesey erreish ny goan shoh y livrey, dy ghow yn pobble yindyss mooar jeh’n ynsagh echey.

English: For he taught them as one having authority, and not as the scribes.
Manx: 29 Son dynsee Eh ad myr fer va pooar echey, as cha nee myr ny scruderyn.
CAB. VIII.

English: When he was come down from the mountain, great multitudes followed him.
Manx: Tra v’eh er jeet neose jeh’n clieau, deiyr earrooyn mooar dy leih er.

English: And, behold, there came a leper and worshipped him, saying, Lord, if thou wilt, thou canst make me clean.
Manx: 2 As cur-my-ner, haink louraane as hug Eh ooashley da, gra, Hiarn, my she dt’aigney eh, foddee oo mish y yannoo glen.

English: And Jesus put forth his hand, and touched him, saying, I will; be thou clean. And immediately his leprosy was cleansed.
Manx: 3 As hug Yeesey magh e laue, as venn Eh rish, gra, M’aigneys eh, bee er dty ghlenney. As chelleeragh va’n louraanys echey er ny ghlenney.

English: And Jesus saith unto him, See thou tell no man; but go thy way, shew thyself to the priest, and offer the gift that Moses commanded, for a testimony unto them.
Manx: 4 As dooyrt Yeesey rish, Jeeagh nagh ninsh oo shoh da dooinney erbee, agh immee, as jeeagh oo hene da’n taggyrt, as cheb yn gioot doardee Moses, dy ve son feanish daue.

English: And when Jesus was entered into Capernaum, there came unto him a centurion, beseeching him,
Manx: 5 ¶ As tra va Yeesey er gholl stiagh ayns Capernaum, haink captan-keead huggey, guee er,

English: And saying, Lord, my servant lieth at home sick of the palsy, grievously tormented.
Manx: 6 As gra, Hiarn, ta my er-mooinjerey ny lhie ec y thie ching jeh’n chingys-cra, ayns stayd feer treih.

English: And Jesus saith unto him, I will come and heal him.
Manx: 7 As dooyrt Yeesey rish, Higg-yms, as nee’m Eh y lheihys.

English: The centurion answered and said, Lord, I am not worthy that thou shouldest come under my roof: but speak the word only, and my servant shall be healed.
Manx: 8 As dreggyr y captan keead gra, Hiarn, Cha vel mee feeu oo dy heet stiagh fo my chlea: agh ny lomarcan loayr y fockle, as bee my er-mooinjerey er ny lheihys.

English: For I am a man under authority, having soldiers under me: and I say to this man, Go, and he goeth; and to another, Come, and he cometh; and to my servant, Do this, and he doeth it
Manx: 9 Son ta mish mee hene my ghooinney ta fo pooar, as ta sidooryn aym foym: as ta mee gra rish y dooinney shoh, Immee, as t’eh goll: as rish fer elley, Tarr, as t’eh cheet: as rish my harvaant, Jean shoh, as t’eh dy yannoo eh.

English: When Jesus heard it, he marvelled, and said to them that followed, Verily I say unto you, I have not found so great faith, no, not in Israel.
Manx: 10 Tra cheayll Yeesey shoh, ghow Eh yindyss, as dooyrt Eh roosyn va geiyrt er, Dy firrinagh ta mee gra riu, Leid y credjue lajer shoh, cha vel mee er gheddyn ayns Israel hene.

English: And I say unto you, That many shall come from the east and west, and shall sit down with Abraham, and Isaac, and Jacob, in the kingdom of heaven.
Manx: 11 As ta mee gra riu, dy jig ymmodee veih’n niar as yn neear, as dy soie ad sheese marish Abraham, as Isaac, as Jacob, ayns reeriaght niau.

English: But the children of the kingdom shall be cast out into outer darkness: there shall be weeping and gnashing of teeth.
Manx: 12 Agh bee cloan y reeriaght er nyn dilgey magh gys y dorraghys sodjey mooie: ayns shen vees keaney as snaggeraght feeacklyn.

English: And Jesus said unto the centurion, Go thy way; and as thou hast believed, so be it done unto thee. And his servant was healed in the selfsame hour.
Manx: 13 As dooyrt Yeesey rish y captan-keead, Immee royd, as ’naght myr t’ow er chredjal, myr shen dy jig oo jeh. As va e er-mooinjerey er ny lheihys ayns yn oor cheddin.

English: And when Jesus was come into Peter's house, he saw his wife's mother laid, and sick of a fever.
Manx: 14 ¶ As tra va Yeesey er jeet stiagh ayns thie Pheddyr, honnick Eh moir y ven echey ny lhie, as ching ayns y chiassaghey.

English: And he touched her hand, and the fever left her: and she arose, and ministered unto them.
Manx: 15 As venn Eh rish y laue eck, as daag y chiassaghey ee: as ren ee girree, as ad y hirveish.

English: When the even was come, they brought unto him many that were possessed with devils: and he cast out the spirits with his word, and healed all that were sick:
Manx: 16 ¶ Tra va’n fastyr er-jeet, hug ad lhieu huggey ymmodee va drogh-spyrrydyn ayndoo: as deiyr Eh magh ny spyrrydyn lesh fockle, as laanee Eh ooilley ny va ching:

English: That it might be fulfilled which was spoken by Esaias the prophet, saying, Himself took our infirmities, and bare our sicknesses.
Manx: 17 Dy voddagh shen ve cooilleenit va loayrit liorish Esaias y Phadeyr, gra, Ghow Eh hene er nyn aslaïntyn, as dymmyrk Eh nyn jingyssyn.

English: Now when Jesus saw great multitudes about him, he gave commandment to depart unto the other side.
Manx: 18 Nish tra honnick Yeesey earrooyn mooarey dy leih mygeayrt-y mysh, hug Eh saarey dy gholl gys y cheu elley.

English: And a certain scribe came, and said unto him, Master, I will follow thee whithersoever thou goest.
Manx: 19 As haink scrudere dy row huggey, as dooyrt Eh rish, Vainshtyr, eiyr-yms ort raad erbee dy jeu.

English: And Jesus saith unto him, The foxes have holes, and the birds of the air have nests; but the Son of man hath not where to lay his head.
Manx: 20 As dooyrt Yeesey rish, Ta tuill ec ny shynnee, as idd ec eeanlee’n aer, agh ec Mac y dooinney cha vel boall dy chur e chione ayn.

English: And another of his disciples said unto him, Lord, suffer me first to go and bury my father.
Manx: 21 As dooyrt fer elley jeusyn va sheer geiyrt er rish, Hiarn, cur kied dou hoshiaght goll thie dy oanluckey my ayr*.
* Tra yiow e baase.

English: But Jesus said unto him, Follow me; and let the dead bury their dead.
Manx: 22 Agh dooyrt Yeesey rish, Eiyr orrym’s, as lig da dy [sic: ny] merriu nyn merriu y oanluckey.

English: And when he was entered into a ship, his disciples followed him.
Manx: 23 ¶ As tra v’eh er ghoaill luingys, hie yn vooinjer va sheer geiyrt er marish.

English: And, behold, there arose a great tempest in the sea, insomuch that the ship was covered with the waves: but he was asleep.
Manx: 24 As cur-my-ner, dirree sterrym mooar ayns y cheayn, ayns wheesh as dy row yn lhong coodit lesh ny tonnyn: agh ve eshyn ny chadley.

English: And his disciples came to him, and awoke him, saying, Lord, save us: we perish.
Manx: 25 As haink adsyn va sheer geiyrt er huggey, as ghooisht ad Eh, gra, Hiarn, saue shin: bee mad callit.

English: And he saith unto them, Why are ye fearful, O ye of little faith? Then he arose, and rebuked the winds and the sea; and there was a great calm.
Manx: 26. As dooyrt Eh roo, Cre’n-fa ta shiu agglagh, shiuish dy chredjue moal? Eisht dirree Eh seose as smaghtee Eh ny geayghyn as y faarkey, as va kuiney vooar ayn.

English: But the men marvelled, saying, What manner of man is this, that even the winds and the sea obey him
Manx: 27 Agh ghow ny deiney yindyss, gra, Cre’n keint dy ghooinney Eh shoh, dy vel ny eer geayghyn as y faarkey cur biallys da!

English: And when he was come to the other side into the country of the Gergesenes, there met him two possessed with devils, coming out of the tombs, exceeding fierce, so that no man might pass by that way.
Manx: 28 ¶ As tra v’eh er jeet gys y cheu elley gys cheer ny Gergesenee haink daa ghooinney va drogh-spyrrydyn ayndoo magh ny whail, veih mastey ny hoiaghyn, as cha keoie shen v’ad, nagh by-loys da dooinney erbee goll shiaghey yn raad shen.

English: And, behold, they cried out, saying, What have we to do with thee, Jesus, thou Son of God? art thou come hither to torment us before the time?
Manx: 29 As cur-my-ner, deïe ad, gra, Cre’n eïe t’ayd orrin, Yeesey Vac Yee? vel oo er jeet dy nyn dorchaghey roish y traa?

English: And there was a good way off from them an herd of many swine feeding.
Manx: 30 As va foddey vow griagh mooar dy vuckyn fo bochillyn.

English: So the devils besought him, saying, If thou cast us out, suffer us to go away into the herd of swine.
Manx: 31 As ghuee ny drogh-spyrrydyn er, gra, My eiyrys oo shin magh, cur kied dooin goll stiagh ayns ny muckyn.

English: And he said unto them, Go. And when they were come out, they went into the herd of swine: and, behold, the whole herd of swine ran violently down a steep place into the sea, and perished in the waters.
Manx: 32 As dooyrt Eh roo, Gow-jee reue. As tra v’ad er jeet ass ny deiney, hie ad stiagh ayns y ghriagh dy vuckyn: as cur-my-ner, roie yn slane ghriagh gouyr nyn mullee lesh yn ughtagh gys y cheayn, as v’ad baiht ayns ny ushtaghyn.

English: And they that kept them fled, and went their ways into the city, and told every thing, and what was befallen to the possessed of the devils.
Manx: 33 As roie ny bochillyn roue, as haink ad gys yn ard-valley, as dinsh ad dy chooilley nhee; as mychione ny deiney va ny drogh-spyrrydyn ayndoo.

English: And, behold, the whole city came out to meet Jesus: and when they saw him, they besought him that he would depart out of their coasts.
Manx: 34 As cur-my-ner, haink y slane ard-valley magh quail Yeesey, as tra honnick ad Eh, ghuee ad er Eh dy gholl roish ass ny ardjyn oc.
CAB. IX.

English: And he entered into a ship, and passed over, and came into his own city.
Manx: As ghow Eh luingys, as hioïll Eh harrish, as haink Eh gys e ard-valley hene.

English: And, behold, they brought to him a man sick of the palsy, lying on a bed: and Jesus seeing their faith said unto the sick of the palsy; Son, be of good cheer; thy sins be forgiven thee.
Manx: 2 As cur-my-ner, hug ad lhieu huggey dooinney va ching jeh’n chingys-cra, ny lhie er lhiabbee: as hug Yeesey tastey da’n chredjue oc, dooyrt Eh rishyn va ching jeh’n chingys-cra, Vac, bee dy yien mie, ta dty pheccaghyn er nyn leih dhyt.

English: And, behold, certain of the scribes said within themselves, This man blasphemeth.
Manx: 3 As cur-my-ner, dooyrt shiartance jeh ny scruderyn roo hene, T’eh shoh loayrt goan mollaghtagh.

English: And Jesus knowing their thoughts said, Wherefore think ye evil in your hearts?
Manx: 4 As hooig Yeesey ny smooinaghtyn oc, as dooyrt Eh, Cre’n-fa ta drogh smooinaghtyn ayns ny creeaghyn eu?

English: For whether is easier, to say, Thy sins be forgiven thee; or to say, Arise, and walk?
Manx: 5 Son quoi sassey dy ghra, Ta dty pheccaghyn er nyn leih dhyt? ny dy ghra, Irree seose as shooill?

English: But that ye may know that the Son of man hath power on earth to forgive sins, (then saith he to the sick of the palsy,) Arise, take up thy bed, and go unto thine house.
Manx: 6 Agh dy vod fys y ve eu, dy vel pooar ec Mac y dooinney er y thalloo dy leih peccaghyn: (eisht doort Eh rishyn va ching jeh’n chingys-cra) Irree, trogg lhiat dty lhiabbee, as gow royd gys dty hie.

English: And he arose, and departed to his house.
Manx: 7 As dirree Eh seose, as jimmee Eh gys e hie.

English: But when the multitudes saw it, they marvelled, and glorified God, which had given such power unto men.
Manx: 8 Agh tra honnick y pobble shoh, ghow ad yindyss, as hug ad moylley da Jee, v’er choyrt leid y phooar da deiney.

English: And as Jesus passed forth from thence, he saw a man, named Matthew, sitting at the receipt of custom: and he saith unto him, Follow me. And he arose, and followed him.
Manx: 9 As tra va Yeesey er gholl veih shen, honnick Eh dooinney va enmyssit Mian, ny hoie ec boayrd y cheesh: as dooyrt Eh rish, Eiyr orryms. As dirree Eh seose as deiyr Eh er.

English: And it came to pass, as Jesus sat at meat in the house, behold, many publicans and sinners came and sat down with him and his disciples.
Manx: 10 ¶ As haink eh gy kione, myr va Yeesey ny hoie ec bee ayns y thie, cur-my-ner, haink ymmodee publicanee as peccee, as hoie ad sheese marishyn as marish y vooinjer va sheer geiyrt er.

English: And when the Pharisees saw it, they said unto his disciples, Why eateth your Master with publicans and sinners?
Manx: 11 Tra honnick ny Phariseeyn shoh, dooyrt ad roosyn va sheer marish, Cre’n-fa ta’n mainshtyr eu gee marish publicanee as peccee?

English: But when Jesus heard that, he said unto them, They that be whole need not a physician, but they that are sick.
Manx: 12 Agh cheayll Yeesey ad, as dooyrt Eh roo, Cha vel feme ocsyn ta slaane er y lhee, agh ec sleih chingey.

English: But go ye and learn what that meaneth, I will have mercy, and not sacrifice: for I am not come to call the righteous, but sinners to repentance.
Manx: 13 Agh gow-jee shiuish, as ynsee-jee cre ta dy ve toiggit liorish y raa shoh, Ta mee ny sbooie er myghin na oural: son cha daink mish dy eamagh er y vooinjer chairagh, agh er peccee gys arrys.

English: Then came to him the disciples of John, saying, Why do we and the Pharisees fast oft, but thy disciples fast not?
Manx: 14 ¶ Eisht haink huggey adsyn va sheer geiyrt er Ean, as dooyrt ad, Cre’n-fa ta shinyn as ny Phariseeyn trostey dy mennick, agh cha vel adsyn ta geiyrt orts trostey?

English: And Jesus said unto them, Can the children of the bridechamber mourn, as long as the bridegroom is with them? but the days will come, when the bridegroom shall be taken from them, and then shall they fast.
Manx: 15 As dooyrt Yeesey roo, Vod ny caarjyn ta marish dooinney’n phoosee ayns e hiamyr ve er drogh yien, choud as ta dooinney’n phoosee mâroo? agh hig ny laghyn, tra vees dooinney’n phoosee er ny ghoaill ersooyl vow, as shen y tra nee ad trostey.

English: No man putteth a piece of new cloth unto an old garment, for that which is put in to fill it up taketh from the garment, and the rent is made worse.
Manx: 16 Cha vel dooinney erbee cur peesh dy eaddagh lajer er shen gharmad: son ta’n pheesh goaill y laane ass y gharmad, as te rapit ny smessey ny ve.

English: Neither do men put new wine into old bottles: else the bottles break, and the wine runneth out, and the bottles perish: but they put new wine into new bottles, and both are preserved.
Manx: 17 Cha moo ta sleih coyrt feeyn noa ayns shenn voteïlyn*: er nonney ta ny boteïlyn brishey, as ta’n feeyn deayrtit, as ta ny boteïlyn dy choayll orroo; agh t’ad cur feeyn noa ayns boteïlyn noa, as t’ad ny neesht sauchey.
* Liare.

English: While he spake these things unto them, behold, there came a certain ruler, and worshipped him, saying, My daughter is even now dead: but come and lay thy hand upon her, and she shall live.
Manx: 18 ¶ Choud as v’eh loayrt ny goan shoh roo, cur-my-ner, haink fer-reil as hug Eh ooashley da, gra, Ta m’inneen nish er gheddyn baase: agh tarr as cur dty laue urree, as bee ee bio reesht.

English: And Jesus arose, and followed him, and so did his disciples.
Manx: 19 As dirree Yeesey as deiyr Eh er, as myr shen ren yn vooinjer va sheer marish.

English: And, behold, a woman, which was diseased with an issue of blood twelve years, came behind him, and touched the hem of his garment:
Manx: 20 ¶ (As cur-my-ner, haink ben cheu-y-choolloo, va doghanit lesh roih-foalley [sic] rish daa vleïn jeig, as venn ee rish oirr e gharmad.

English: For she said within herself, If I may but touch his garment, I shall be whole.
Manx: 21 Son dooyrt ee cheu-sthie jee hene, My oddym agh bennaylt rish e gharmad bee-ym er my lheihys.

English: But Jesus turned him about, and when he saw her, he said, Daughter, be of good comfort; thy faith hath made thee whole. And the woman was made whole from that hour.
Manx: 22 Agh hyndaa Yeesey mygeayrt, as tra honnick Eh ee, dooyrt Eh, Inneen, bee dy yien mie; ta dty chredjue er dty laanaghey. As va’n ven er ny lheihys veih’n oor shen.)

English: And when Jesus came into the ruler's house, and saw the minstrels and the people making a noise,
Manx: 23 As tra va Yeesey er-jeet stiagh ayns thie yn fer-reil, as tra honnick Eh yn vooinjer va jannoo kiaull as y cheshaght ooilley ayns feiyr hrimshagh,

English: He said unto them, Give place: for the maid is not dead, but sleepeth. And they laughed him to scorn.
Manx: 24 Dooyrt Eh roo, Scugh-jee as y raad, son cha vel y ven-aeg marroo, agh ny cadley. As hie ad son craidey mysh.

English: But when the people were put forth, he went in, and took her by the hand, and the maid arose.
Manx: 25 Agh tra va’n sleih er nyn eiyrt magh, hie Eh stiagh, as ghow Eh ee er laue, as dirree yn ven-aeg seose.

English: And the fame hereof went abroad into all that land.
Manx: 26 As hie goo magh jeh shoh trooid ooilley’n cheer.

English: And when Jesus departed thence, two blind men followed him, crying, and saying, Thou son of David, have mercy on us.
Manx: 27 ¶ As tra va Yeesey er gholl veih shen, deiyr daa ghooinney doal er, geamagh as gra, Jean chymmey orrin, Vac Ghavid.

English: And when he was come into the house, the blind men came to him: and Jesus saith unto them, Believe ye that I am able to do this? They said unto him, Yea, Lord.
Manx: 28 As tra v’eh er jeet stiagh ayns y thie, haink ny deiney doal huggey: as dooyrt Yeesey roo, Vel shiu credjal dy vel mish abyl shoh y yannoo? Dooyrt adsyn rish, Ta, Hiarn.

English: Then touched he their eyes, saying, According to your faith be it unto you.
Manx: 29 Eisht venn Eh rish ny sooyllyn oc, gra Cordail rish nyn gredjue dy row nyn aghin eu.

English: And their eyes were opened; and Jesus straitly charged them, saying, See that no man know it.
Manx: 30 As va ny sooyllyn oc er nyn vosley, as hug Yeesey currym gyere daue, gra, Jeeagh-jee nagh vow dooinney erbee fys er.

English: But they, when they were departed, spread abroad his fame in all that country.
Manx: 31 Agh tra v’adsyn er gholl roue, hug ad goo jeh magh trooid ooilley’n cheer shen.

English: As they went out, behold, they brought to him a dumb man possessed with a devil.
Manx: 32 ¶ Erreish daue shoh v’er gholl ersooyl, cur-my-ner, hug ad lhieu huggey dooinney balloo, va drogh-spyrryd ayn.

English: And when the devil was cast out, the dumb spake: and the multitudes marvelled, saying, It was never so seen in Israel.
Manx: 33 As tra va’n drogh-spyrryd er ny eiyrt ass, ren y balloo loayrt: as ghow yn pobble yindyss, gra, Cha row rieau leid shoh er ny akin ayns Israel.

English: But the Pharisees said, He casteth out devils through the prince of the devils.
Manx: 34 Agh dooyrt ny Phariseeyn, Liorish prince ny drogh-spyrrydyn t’eh tilgey magh drogh-spyrrydyn.

English: And Jesus went about all the cities and villages, teaching in their synagogues, and preaching the gospel of the kingdom, and healing every sickness and every disease among the people.
Manx: 35 As hie Yeesey mygeayrt ooilley ny ard-valjyn as ny baljyn beggey oc, gynsaghey ayns ny kialteenyn oc, as preacheil sushtal yn reeriaght, as lheihys dy chooilley hingys as dy chooilley ghoghan mastey’n pobble.

English: But when he saw the multitudes, he was moved with compassion on them, because they fainted, and were scattered abroad, as sheep having no shepherd.
Manx: 36 ¶ Agh tra honnick Eh yn chaglym mooar dy leih, v’eh er ny veiyghey lesh chymmey orroo, er-yn-oyr dy row ad ass cree, as nyn lhie noon as noal, myr kirree fegooish bochilley.

English: Then saith he unto his disciples, The harvest truly is plenteous, but the labourers are few;
Manx: 37 Eisht dooyrt Eh roosyn va sheer geiyrt er, Ta’n fouyr dy jarroo palchey, agh ny labreeyn beggan.

English: Pray ye therefore the Lord of the harvest, that he will send forth labourers into his harvest.
Manx: 38 Guee-jee shiuish er-y-fa shen er Chiarn y fouyr, Eh dy chur magh labreeyn gys y fouyr echey.
CAB. X.

English: And when he had called unto him his twelve disciples, he gave them power against unclean spirits, to cast them out, and to heal all manner of sickness and all manner of disease.
Manx: As tra v’eh er n’eamagh er e ghaa ostyl jeig huggey, hug Eh daue pooar harrish spyrrydyn neu-ghlen, dy eiyrt ad magh, as dy lheihys dy chooilley vonney dy hingys, as dy chooilley ghoghan.

English: Now the names of the twelve apostles are these; The first, Simon, who is called Peter, and Andrew his brother; James the son of Zebedee, and John his brother;
Manx: 2 As shoh va enmyn yn daa ostyl yeig; Yn chied er, Simon, ta enmyssit Peddyr, as Andreays e vraar, Jamys mac Zebedee, as Ean y braar echyssyn,

English: Philip, and Bartholomew; Thomas, and Matthew the publican; James the son of Alphaeus, and Lebbaeus, whose surname was Thaddaeus;
Manx: 3 Philip as Parlane, Thomase, as Mian yn publican, Jamys mac Alpheus, as Lebbeus va slennooit Thaddeus,

English: Simon the Canaanite, and Judas Iscariot, who also betrayed him.
Manx: 4 Simon yn Canaanite, as Yuaase Iscariot, ren myrgeddin Eh y vrah.

English: These twelve Jesus sent forth, and commanded them, saying, Go not into the way of the Gentiles, and into any city of the Samaritans enter ye not:
Manx: 5 Yn ghaa yeig shoh hug Yeesey magh, as doardee Eh daue, gra, Ny gow-jee ayns raad ny Ashoonyn-quaagh, ny gys ard-valjyn ny Samaritanee.

English: But go rather to the lost sheep of the house of Israel.
Manx: 6 Agh gow-jee hoshiaght gys kirree cailjey thie Israel.

English: And as ye go, preach, saying, The kingdom of heaven is at hand.
Manx: 7 As myr vees shiu goll, jean-jee preacheil, gra, Ta reeriaght niau er-gerrey.

English: Heal the sick, cleanse the lepers, raise the dead, cast out devils: freely ye have received, freely give.
Manx: 8 Slaanee-jee sleih chingey, glen-jee ny louraanee, jean-jee ny merriu y vioghey, tilg-jee magh drogh-spyrrydyn: nastee ta shiu er gheddyn, as dy nastee cur-jee veu.

English: Provide neither gold, nor silver, nor brass in your purses,
Manx: 9 Ny cur-jee lhieu airh, ny argid, ny prash ayns ny sporranyn eu:

English: Nor scrip for your journey, neither two coats, neither shoes, nor yet staves: for the workman is worthy of his meat.
Manx: 10 Ny stoyr dy vee son y raad, ny daa chooat, ny braagyn, ny luirg: (son ta’n obbree feeu e veaghey)

English: And into whatsoever city or town ye shall enter, enquire who in it is worthy; and there abide till ye go thence.
Manx: 11 As ard-valley ny balley erbee dy jed shiu stiagh ayn, fênee-jee quoi ayn ta feeu, as marishyn fuirree-jee derrey hed shiu reue.

English: And when ye come into an house, salute it.
Manx: 12 As tra vees shiu goll stiagh ayns thie, bannee-jee daue.

English: And if the house be worthy, let your peace come upon it: but if it be not worthy, let your peace return to you.
Manx: 13 As my vees y thie feeu, lig da’n shee eu cheet er: agh mannagh bee eh feeu, lig da’n shee eu chyndaa hiu hene reesht.

English: And whosoever shall not receive you, nor hear your words, when ye depart out of that house or city, shake off the dust of your feet.
Manx: 14 As quoi-erbee nagh jean nyn mea y oltaghey, as nagh der geill da ny goan eu: tra aagys shiu yn thie ny’n ard-valley shen, crie-jee yn joan jeh ny cassyn eu.

English: Verily I say unto you, It shall be more tolerable for the land of Sodom and Gomorrha in the day of judgment, than for that city.
Manx: 15 Dy firrinagh ta mee gra riu, Dy vow cheer Sodom as Gomorrah ny smoo dy foayr, ec laa ny briwnys, na yiow yn ard-valley shen.

English: Behold, I send you forth as sheep in the midst of wolves: be ye therefore wise as serpents, and harmless as doves.
Manx: 16 ¶ Cur-my-ner, ta mish dyn goyrt shiu magh myr kirree mastey moddee oaldey: Bee-jee er-y-fa shen tastagh myr ard-nieughyn, as gyn loght myr calmaneyn.

English: But beware of men: for they will deliver you up to the councils, and they will scourge you in their synagogues;
Manx: 17 Agh cur-jee twoaie jeh deiney, son livrey-ee ad shiu seose gys ny coonceilyn, as custee ad shiu ayns ny quaiyllyn oc.

English: And ye shall be brought before governors and kings for my sake, for a testimony against them and the Gentiles.
Manx: 18 As bee shiu er nyn goyrt fenish kiannoortyn as reeaghyn er y choontey ayms, dy vod oyr y ve eu feanish y ymmyrkey dauesyn * as da ny Ashoonyn-quaagh.
* Jeh’n Chredjue Crestee.

English: But when they deliver you up, take no thought how or what ye shall speak: for it shall be given you in that same hour what ye shall speak.
Manx: 19 Agh tra livrey-ys ad shiu seose, ny bee-jee imneagh kys, ny cre nee shiu y loayrt, son bee eh er ny choyrt diu ayns yn oor cheddin cre nee shiu y loayrt.

English: For it is not ye that speak, but the Spirit of your Father which speaketh in you.
Manx: 20 Son cha nee shiuish ta loayrt, agh spyrryd yn Ayr eu ta loayrt ayndiu.

English: And the brother shall deliver up the brother to death, and the father the child: and the children shall rise up against their parents, and cause them to be put to death.
Manx: 21 As livrey-ee yn derrey vraar yn braar elley gys baase, as yn ayr y liannoo: as nee cloan girree seose noi nyn ayr as nyn moir, as eiyree ad ad gys baase.

English: And ye shall be hated of all men for my name's sake: but he that endureth to the end shall be saved.
Manx: 22 As ver dy chooilley ghooinney feoh diu, er coontey yn ennym ayms: agh eshyn nee cummal magh gys y jerrey, vees er ny hauail.

English: But when they persecute you in this city, flee ye into another: for verily I say unto you, Ye shall not have gone over the cities of Israel, till the Son of man be come.
Manx: 23 Agh tra vees ad jannoo tranlaase erriu ’sy derrey ard-valley, roih-jee shiuish er-chea gys ard-valley elley: son dy firrinagh ta mee gra riu, Dy bee Mac y dooinney er-jeet*, roish my bee shiu er gholl harrish ard-valjyn Israel.
* Dy stroie ard-valley as ashoon ny Hewnyn.

English: The disciple is not above his master, nor the servant above his lord.
Manx: 24 Cha vel y scoyllar erskyn e vainshtyr, ny’n charvaant erskyn e hiarn.

English: It is enough for the disciple that he be as his master, and the servant as his lord. If they have called the master of the house Beelzebub, how much more shall they call them of his household?
Manx: 25 Slioyr da’n scoyllar dy ve myr e vainshtyr, as y charvaant myr e hiarn: my t’ad er cheau Beelzebub er mainshtyr y thie, cre woad smoo nee ad e vooinjer y oltooaney?

English: Fear them not therefore: for there is nothing covered, that shall not be revealed; and hid, that shall not be known.
Manx: 26 Ny gow-jee er-y-fa shen aggle roue: son cha vel nhee erbee follit nagh jig gys soilshey; ny nhee erbee kellit, nagh jig magh.

English: What I tell you in darkness, that speak ye in light: and what ye hear in the ear, that preach ye upon the housetops.
Manx: 27 Shen ta mish dy insh diu ayns y dorraghys, loayr-jee shiuish jeh ayns y toilshey: as ny ta shiu er chlashtyn ayns y chleash eu voym’s, jean-jee y phreacheil er mullagh ny thieyn.

English: And fear not them which kill the body, but are not able to kill the soul: but rather fear him which is able to destroy both soul and body in hell.
Manx: 28 As ny bee-jee agglagh rouesyn varrys y corp, agh nagh jiarg er yn annym y varroo: agh bee-jee ayns aggle smoo roishyn oddys corp as annym neesht y stroie ayns niurin.

English: Are not two sparrows sold for a farthing? and one of them shall not fall on the ground without your Father.
Manx: 29 Nagh vel daa sparroo er nyn greck son farling? as cha duitt annane oc marroo er y thalloo fegooish oardagh yn Ayr eu.

English: But the very hairs of your head are all numbered.
