English: Then assembled together the chief priests, and the scribes, and the elders of the people, unto the palace of the high priest, who was called Caiaphas,
Manx: 3 Eisht va ny ard-saggyrtyn as ny scruderyn as shanstyr y pobble er nyn jaglym cooidjagh gys thie yn ard-saggyrt va enmyssit Caiaphas,

English: And consulted that they might take Jesus by subtilty, and kill him.
Manx: 4 As hug ad nyn goyrle dy-cheilley, mychione Yeesey y ghoaill dy follit, as y choyrt Eh gy baase.

English: But they said, Not on the feast day, lest there be an uproar among the people.
Manx: 5 Agh dooyrt ad, cha nee er laa yn eailley, er aggle dy bee irree-magh ayn mastey yn pobble.

English: Now when Jesus was in Bethany, in the house of Simon the leper,
Manx: 6 ¶ Nish tra va Yeesey ayns Bethany, ayns thie Simon yn louraane,

English: There came unto him a woman having an alabaster box of very precious ointment, and poured it on his head, as he sat at meat.
Manx: 7 Haink huggey ben as box alabaster dy ooill feer deyr eck, as gheayrt ee eh er y chione echey, myr v’eh ny hoie ec bee.

English: But when his disciples saw it, they had indignation, saying, To what purpose is this waste?
Manx: 8 Agh tra honnick y vooinjer va sheer geiyrt er shoh, v’ad jymmo[o]sagh, gra, Cre’n-fa va’n jummal shoh jeant?

English: For this ointment might have been sold for much, and given to the poor.
Manx: 9 Son oddagh yn ooill shoh v’er ny ve creckit son mooarane, as er ny choyrt da ny boghtyn.

English: When Jesus understood it, he said unto them, Why trouble ye the woman? for she hath wrought a good work upon me.
Manx: 10 Tra hoig Yeesey shoh, dooyrt Eh roo, Kys dy vel shiu boirey yn ven? son t’ee er n’obbraghey obbyr vie orrym’s.

English: For ye have the poor always with you; but me ye have not always.
Manx: 11 Son ta ny boghtyn eu kinjagh mêriu, agh mish cha vel eu kinjagh.

English: For in that she hath poured this ointment on my body, she did it for my burial.
Manx: 12 Son liorish dy vel ee er gheayrtey yn ooill shoh er my chorp, t’ee er n’yannoo eh gouyr my oanluckey.

English: Verily I say unto you, Wheresoever this gospel shall be preached in the whole world, there shall also this, that this woman hath done, be told for a memorial of her.
Manx: 13 Dy firrinagh ta mee gra riu, Raad erbee dy bee yn sushtal shoh er ny phreacheil ayns ooilley’n theihll, bee shoh myrgeddin ta’n ven shoh er n’yannoo, er ny insh son cooinaghtyn jee.

English: Then one of the twelve, called Judas Iscariot, went unto the chief priests,
Manx: 14 ¶ Eisht hie fer jeh’n daa ostyl yeig, va enmyssit Yuaase Iscariot, gys ny ard saggyrtyn,

English: And said unto them, What will ye give me, and I will deliver him unto you? And they covenanted with him for thirty pieces of silver.
Manx: 15 As dooyrt Eh roo, Cre ver shiu dooys, as livrey’m Eh hiu? As ren ad conaant rish son jeih peeshyn as feed dy argid.

English: And from that time he sought opportunity to betray him.
Manx: 16 As veih’n traa shen v’eh shirrey caa dy vrah eh.

English: Now the first day of the feast of unleavened bread the disciples came to Jesus, saying unto him, Where wilt thou that we prepare for thee to eat the passover?
Manx: 17 ¶ Nish er y chied laa jeh feailley yn arran millish, haink y vooinjer va sheer geiyrt er Yeesey huggey, as dooyrt ad rish, Cre’n raad sailt shin dy yannoo aarloo er dy [sic: dty] hon dy ee yn Eayn caisht?

English: And he said, Go into the city to such a man, and say unto him, The Master saith, My time is at hand; I will keep the passover at thy house with my disciples.
Manx: 18 As dooyrt Eh, Gow-jee gys yn ard-valley gys leid y dooinney shen, as abyr-jee rish, Ta’n mainshtyr gra, Ta my hraa ec laue, freill-ym y chaisht ec dty hie’s marish y vooinjer ta sheer geiyrt orrym.

English: And the disciples did as Jesus had appointed them; and they made ready the passover.
Manx: 19 As ren adsyn myr va Yeesey er n’oardaghey daue, as daarlee ad yn Eayn caisht.

English: Now when the even was come, he sat down with the twelve.
Manx: 20 Nish tra va’n fastyr er-jeet, hoie Eh sheese marish yn daa ostyl yeig.

English: And as they did eat, he said, Verily I say unto you, that one of you shall betray me.
Manx: 21 As myr v’ad gee, dooyrt Eh, Dy firrinagh ta mee gra riu, dy jean annane eauish mish y vrah.

English: And they were exceeding sorrowful, and began every one of them to say unto him, Lord, is it I?
Manx: 22 As v’ad feer trimshagh, as ren ad toshiaght dy chooilley annane oc dy ghra rish, Hiarn, nee orryms t’ow cheet?

English: And he answered and said, He that dippeth his hand with me in the dish, the same shall betray me.
Manx: 23 As dansoor eshyn, gra, Eshyn ta thummey e laue mârym ayns y chlaare, Eh shen nee mee y vrah.

English: The Son of man goeth as it is written of him: but woe unto that man by whom the Son of man is betrayed! it had been good for that man if he had not been born.
Manx: 24 Ta’n Mac dooinney goll, myr te scruit jeh: agh smerg da’n dooinney shen liorish vees yn Mac dooinney er ny vrah: veagh eh er ny ve mie son y dooinney shen, mannagh beagh Eh jeet er y theihll.

English: Then Judas, which betrayed him, answered and said, Master, is it I? He said unto him, Thou hast said.
Manx: 25 Eisht dansoor Yuaase, ren y vrah Eh, as dooyrt Eh, Vainshtyr, nee mish Eh? Dooyrt eshyn rish, T’ow er ghra eh.

English: And as they were eating, Jesus took bread, and blessed it, and brake it, and gave it to the disciples, and said, Take, eat; this is my body.
Manx: 26 ¶ As myr v’ad gee, ghow Yeesey arran, as vannee Eh as vrish Eh eh, as hug Eh eh da ny ostyllyn, gra, Gow-jee, ee-jee, shoh my chorp’s.

English: And he took the cup, and gave thanks, and gave it to them, saying, Drink ye all of it;
Manx: 27 As ghow Eh yn cappan, as hug Eh booise, as hug Eh eh daue, gra, Iu-jee ooilley jeh shoh.

English: For this is my blood of the new testament, which is shed for many for the remission of sins.
Manx: 28 Son shoh my uill’s jeh’n conaant noa, t’er ny gheayrtey son ymmodee son leih peccaghyn.

English: But I say unto you, I will not drink henceforth of this fruit of the vine, until that day when I drink it new with you in my Father's kingdom.
Manx: 29 Agh ta mee gra riu, Nagh niu-ym maghey shoh jeh mess y villey-feeney, derrey’n laa iu-ym eh as yn noa mêriu ayns reeriaght my Ayrey.

English: And when they had sung an hymn, they went out into the mount of Olives.
Manx: 30 As tra v’ad er ghoaill arrane spyrrydoil, hie ad magh gys cronck ny Oliveyn.

English: Then saith Jesus unto them, All ye shall be offended because of me this night: for it is written, I will smite the shepherd, and the sheep of the flock shall be scattered abroad.
Manx: 31 Eisht dooyrt Yeesey roo, Failee yn credjue eauish ooilley noght kyndagh rhym’s: son te scruit, Bwoaillym’s yn bochilley, as bee kirree yn chioltane er nyn skeayley.

English: But after I am risen again, I will go before you into Galilee.
Manx: 32 Agh erreish dou v’er n’irree reesht, hem reue gys Galilee.

English: Peter answered and said unto him, Though all men shall be offended because of thee, yet will I never be offended.
Manx: 33 Dansoor Peddyr as dooyrt Eh rish, Ga dy vaill credjue dy chooilley ghooinney kyndagh rhyts, cha vaill my chredjue’s dy bragh.

English: Jesus said unto him, Verily I say unto thee, That this night, before the cock crow, thou shalt deny me thrice.
Manx: 34 Dooyrt Yeesey rish, Dy firrinagh ta mee gra rhyt, yn oie noght roish my gerr yn kellagh, dy nob uss mish three keayrtyn.

English: Peter said unto him, Though I should die with thee, yet will I not deny thee. Likewise also said all the disciples.
Manx: 35 Dooyrt Peddyr rish, Dy beïn dy gholl gy baase mârt, cha nobbin oo. As er yn aght cheddin loayr ooilley ny ostyllyn.

English: Then cometh Jesus with them unto a place called Gethsemane, and saith unto the disciples, Sit ye here, while I go and pray yonder.
Manx: 36 ¶ Eisht haink Yeesey mâroo gys ynnyd va enmyssit Gethsemane, as dooyrt Eh rish ny ostyllyn, Soie-jee shiuish ayns shoh, choud as hem’s gys padjer ayns shid.

English: And he took with him Peter and the two sons of Zebedee, and began to be sorrowful and very heavy.
Manx: 37 As ghow Eh marish Peddyr, as daa vac Zebedee, as ren Eh toshiaght dy ve trimshagh as trome-chreeagh.

English: Then saith he unto them, My soul is exceeding sorrowful, even unto death: tarry ye here, and watch with me.
Manx: 38 Eisht dooyrt Eh roo, Ta my annym feer trimshagh, dy jarroo gys y baase: fuirree-jee ayns shoh as jean-jee watchal mârym.

English: And he went a little farther, and fell on his face, and prayed, saying, O my Father, if it be possible, let this cup pass from me: nevertheless not as I will, but as thou wilt.
Manx: 39 As hie Eh red beg sodjey, as huit Eh sheese er e eddin, as ghow Eh padjer, as dooyrt Eh, O my Ayr, my te possible, lig da’n cappan shoh goll shiagh-ym: ny-yeih cha nee m’aigney’s, agh dt’aigneys dy row jeant.

English: And he cometh unto the disciples, and findeth them asleep, and saith unto Peter, What, could ye not watch with me one hour?
Manx: 40 As haink Eh gys ny ostyllyn, as hooar Eh ad nyn gadley, as dooyrt eh rish Peddyr, Kys ta shoh, nagh row shiu abyl watchal mârym un oor?

English: Watch and pray, that ye enter not into temptation: the spirit indeed is willing, but the flesh is weak.
Manx: 41 Bee-jee er nyn dwoaie as guee-jee, nagh duit shiu ayns miolagh: ta’n spyrryd dy jarroo arryltagh, agh ta’n eill annoon.

English: He went away again the second time, and prayed, saying, O my Father, if this cup may not pass away from me, except I drink it, thy will be done.
Manx: 42 Hie Eh roish reesht yn nah cheayrt, as ghow Eh padjer, gra, O my Ayr, mannagh vod y cappan shoh goll shiagh-ym, fegooish mee dy iu eh, dt’aigney's dy row jeant.

English: And he came and found them asleep again: for their eyes were heavy.
Manx: 43 As haink Eh as hooar Eh ad nyn gadley reesht: son va ny sooyllyn oc trome.

English: And he left them, and went away again, and prayed the third time, saying the same words.
Manx: 44 As daag Eh ad, as hie Eh roish reesht, as ghow Eh padjer yn tress cheayrt, gra ny goan cheddin.

English: Then cometh he to his disciples, and saith unto them, Sleep on now, and take your rest: behold, the hour is at hand, and the Son of man is betrayed into the hands of sinners.
Manx: 45 Eisht haink Eh gys e ostyllyn, as dooyrt Eh roo, Caidle-jee nish, as gow-jee nyn vea; cur-my-ner, ta’n oor tayrn er-gerrey, as ta’n Mac dooinney er ny vrah gys laueyn peccee.

English: Rise, let us be going: behold, he is at hand that doth betray me.
Manx: 46 Irree-jee, as lig dooin goll: cur-my-ner, te eshyn er-gerrey dooin ta dy my vrah.

English: And while he yet spake, lo, Judas, one of the twelve, came, and with him a great multitude with swords and staves, from the chief priests and elders of the people.
Manx: 47 ¶ As choud as v’eh foast loayrt, cur-my-ner, haink Yuaase, fer jeh’n daa ostyl yeig, as va sheshaght vooar marish lesh cliwnyn as luirg, veih ny ard-saggyrtyn as shanstyr yn pobble.

English: Now he that betrayed him gave them a sign, saying, Whomsoever I shall kiss, that same is he: hold him fast.
Manx: 48 Nish hug eshyn v’er vrah Eh, cowrey daue, gra, Quoi-erbee verrym’s paag da, shen Eh, cum-jee Eh dy shickyr.

English: And forthwith he came to Jesus, and said, Hail, master; and kissed him.
Manx: 49 As chelleeragh haink Eh gys Yeesey, as dooyrt Eh, Dy vannee dhyt Vainshtyr; as phaag Eh Eh.

English: And Jesus said unto him, Friend, wherefore art thou come? Then came they, and laid hands on Jesus and took him.
Manx: 50 As dooyrt Yeesey rish, Charrey, cre’n-fa t’ow er-jeet? Eisht haink ad as hug ad nyn laueyn er Yeesey, as ghow ad Eh.

English: And, behold, one of them which were with Jesus stretched out his hand, and drew his sword, and struck a servant of the high priest’s, and smote off his ear.
Manx: 51 As cur-my-ner, heeyn fer jeusyn va marish Yeesey magh e laue, as hayrn Eh e chliwe, as woail Eh fer-mooinjerey yn ard-saggyrt, as yiare Eh yn chleash jeh.

English: Then said Jesus unto him, Put up again thy sword into his place: for all they that take the sword shall perish with the sword.
Manx: 52 Eisht dooyrt Yeesey rish, Cur seose dty chliwe reesht ayns e ynnyd: son nee adsyn ooilley ta goaill y chliwe, cherraghtyn liorish y chliwe.

English: Thinkest thou that I cannot now pray to my Father, and he shall presently give me more than twelve legions of angels?
Manx: 53 Vel uss goaill as laue nagh voddym’s nish guee gys my Ayr, as yinnagh Eh chelleeragh hym er-skyn daa legion jeig dy ainlyn?

English: But how then shall the scriptures be fulfilled, that thus it must be?
Manx: 54 Agh kys eisht vees ny scripturyn er nyn gooilleeney, dy nee shoh myr te dy ve?

English: In that same hour said Jesus to the multitudes, Are ye come out as against a thief with swords and staves for to take me? I sat daily with you teaching in the temple, and ye laid no hold on me.
Manx: 55 Ayns yn oor cheddin dooyrt Yeesey rish y pobble, Vel shiu er-jeet magh myr noi maarlagh, lesh cliwnyn as luirg dy my ghoaill? Hoie-mee [sic: Hoie mee] mêriu gagh laa gynsaghey ayns y chiamble, as cha ren shiu my ghoaill.

English: But all this was done, that the scriptures of the prophets might be fulfilled. Then all the disciples forsook him, and fled.
Manx: 56 Agh va ooilley shoh jeant, dy voddagh scripturyn ny phadeyryn ve cooilleenit. Eisht ren ooilley ny ostyllyn Eh y hreigeil as cosney rowe.

English: And they that had laid hold on Jesus led him away to Caiaphas the high priest, where the scribes and the elders were assembled.
Manx: 57 ¶ As leeid y vooinjer v’er ghoaill Yeesey Eh ersooyl gys Caiaphas yn ard-saggyrt, raad va ny scruderyn as y chanstyr er nyn jaglym cooidjagh.

English: But Peter followed him afar off unto the high priest’s palace, and went in, and sat with the servants, to see the end.
Manx: 58 Agh deiyr Peddyr er foddey ny yei, gys thie yn ard-saggyrt, as hie Eh stiagh, as hoie Eh marish ny sharvaantyn dy yeeaghyn cre veagh y jerrey.

English: Now the chief priests, and elders, and all the council, sought false witness against Jesus, to put him to death;
Manx: 59 Nish va ny ard-saggyrtyn as y chanstyr as ooilley’n choonceil, shirrey feanish foalsey noi Yeesey dy choyrt Eh gy baase.

English: But found none: yea, though many false witnesses came, yet found they none. At the last came two false witnesses,
Manx: 60 Agh cha dooar ad veg: ga dy daink ymmodee feanishyn foalsey, foast cha dooar ad veg. Ec y jerrey haink daa eanish foalsey,

English: And said, This fellow said, I am able to destroy the temple of God, and to build it in three days.
Manx: 61 As dooyrt ad, T’eh shoh er ghra, Ta mish abyl chiamble Yee y lieggal, as y hroggal eh reesht ayns three laa.

English: And the high priest arose, and said unto him, Answerest thou nothing? what is it which these witness against thee?
Manx: 62 As dirree yn ard-saggyrt seose, as dooyrt Eh rish, Nagh vel oo cur ansoor? Cre t’ad shoh dy hoilshaghey dt’oi?

English: But Jesus held his peace, And the high priest answered and said unto him, I adjure thee by the living God, that thou tell us whether thou be the Christ, the Son of God.
Manx: 63 Agh chum Yeesey e hengey. As dreggyr yn ard-saggyrt as dooyrt Eh rish, Ta mee cur currym ort liorish yn Jee bio, oo dy insh dooin, nee oo yn Creest Mac Yee?

English: Jesus saith unto him, Thou hast said: nevertheless I say unto you, Hereafter shall ye see the Son of man sitting on the right hand of power, and coming in the clouds of heaven.
Manx: 64 Dooyrt Yeesey rish, T’ow uss er ghra eh: ny-yeih ta mish gra riu, Ny lurg shoh hee shiu yn Mac dooinney ny hoie er laue yesh yn phooar, as cheet ayns bodjallyn yn aer.

English: Then the high priest rent his clothes, saying, He hath spoken blasphemy; what further need have we of witnesses? behold, now ye have heard his blasphemy.
Manx: 65 Eisht raip yn ard-saggyrt e eaddagh, gra, T’eh er loayrt goan mollaghtagh, cre’n feme sodjey t’ain er feanishyn? cur-my-ner, nish ta shiu er chlashtyn e ghoan mollaghtagh.

English: What think ye? They answered and said, He is guilty of death.
Manx: 66 Cre ta shiu dy smooinaghtyn? Dansoor ad as dooyrt ad, T’eh toilchin dy ve er ny choyrt gy baase.

English: Then did they spit in his face, and buffeted him; and others smote him with the palms of their hands,
Manx: 67 Eisht chew ad shellaghyn ayns e eddin, as woail ad Eh, as woail feallagh elley Eh lesh bassyn nyn laueyn.

English: Saying, Prophesy unto us, thou Christ, Who is he that smote thee?
Manx: 68 Gra, Jean phadeyrys dooin, uss yn Creest, quoi ta dy dty woalley?

English: Now Peter sat without in the palace: and a damsel came unto him, saying, Thou also wast with Jesus of Galilee.
Manx: 69 ¶ Nish va Peddyr ny hoie cheu-moie jeh’n cheshaght ayns y hall: as haink ben-aeg huggey, gra, V’ow uss myrgeddin marish Yeesey dy Ghalilee.

English: But he denied before them all, saying, I know not what thou sayest.
Manx: 70 Agh dobb Eh kiongoyrt roo ooilley, gra, Cha s’aym cre t’ow dy ghra.

English: And when he was gone out into the porch, another maid saw him, and said unto them that were there, This fellow was also with Jesus of Nazareth.
Manx: 71 As tra v’eh er gholl magh ayns y phorch, honnick ben-aeg elley Eh, as dooyrt ee roosyn v’ayns shen, V’eh shoh myrgeddin marish Yeesey dy Nazareth.

English: And again he denied with an oath, I do not know the man.
Manx: 72 As reesht dobb Eh lesh loo, Cha nione dou yn dooinney.

English: And after a while came unto him they that stood by, and said to Peter, Surely thou also art one of them; for thy speech bewrayeth thee.
Manx: 73 As tammylt ny lurg shen haink huggey yn vooinjer va nyn shassoo liorish, as dooyrt ad rish Peddyr, Shickyr she fer jeu oo, son ta dty ghlare dy dty vrah.

English: Then began he to curse and to swear, saying, I know not the man. And immediately the cock crew.
Manx: 74 Eisht ren Eh toshiaght dy ghweeaghyn as dy loo, gra, Cha nione dou yn dooinney. As chelleeragh gherr yn kellagh.

English: And Peter remembered the word of Jesus, which said unto him, Before the cock crow, thou shalt deny me thrice. And he went out, and wept bitterly.
Manx: 75 As chooinee Peddyr er ny goan va Yeesey er ghra rish, Roish my gerr y kellagh, obbee uss mish three keayrtyn. As hie Eh magh as cheayn eh dy sharroo.
CAB. XXVII.

English: When the morning was come, all the chief priests and elders of the people took counsel against Jesus to put him to death:
Manx: Tra va’n moghrey er-jeet, hug ooilley ny ard-saggyrtyn as shanstyr yn pobble nyn goyrle dy cheilley, dy choyrt Eh gy baase.

English: And when they had bound him, they led him away, and delivered him to Pontius Pilate the governor.
Manx: 2 As erreish daue v’er chiangley Eh, leeid ad Eh ersooyl, as livrey ad Eh gys Pontius Pilate yn kiannoort.

English: Then Judas, which had betrayed him, when he saw that he was condemned, repented himself, and brought again the thirty pieces of silver to the chief priests and elders,
Manx: 3 ¶ Tra honnick eisht Yuaase ren y vrah Eh, dy row Eh er ny gheyrey, ghow Eh arrys, as hug Eh lesh reesht ny jeih peeshyn-as-feed dy argid gys ny ard-saggyrtyn as y chanstyr,

English: Saying, I have sinned in that I have betrayed the innocent blood. And they said, What is that to us? see thou to that.
Manx: 4 Gra, Ta mee er n’yannoo peccah, ayns dy vel mee er vrah yn uill neu-chyndagh. As dooyrt adsyn, Cre ta shen dooinyn? jeeagh uss da shen.

English: And he cast down the pieces of silver in the temple, and departed, and went and hanged himself.
Manx: 5 As hilg Eh sheese ny peeshyn argid ayns y chiamble, as jimmee Eh roish, as hie Eh as ren Eh Eh hene y chroghey.

English: And the chief priests took the silver pieces, and said, It is not lawful for to put them into the treasury, because it is the price of blood.
Manx: 6 As ghow ny ard-saggyrtyn ny peeshyn argid as dooyrt ad, Cha vel eh lowal dy choyrt ad mastey tashtaghyn y chiamble, er-yn-oyr dy nee leagh foalley eh.

English: And they took counsel, and bought with them the potter’s field, to bury strangers in.
Manx: 7 As ghow ad coyrle, as chionnee ad lhieu magher fer-ny-craie, dy oanluckey joarreeyn ayn.

English: Wherefore that field was called, The field of blood, unto this day.
Manx: 8 Shen-y-fa va’n magher shen enmyssit magher foalley gys y laa t’ayn jiu.

English: Then was fulfilled that which was spoken by Jeremy the prophet, saying, And they took the thirty pieces of silver, the price of him that was valued, whom they of the children of Israel did value;
Manx: 9 (Shen y traa va cooilleenit ny va loayrit liorish Jeremy yn phadeyr, gra, As ghow ad ny jeih peeshyn as feed dy argid, yn phrice echyssyn v’er ny phriceil, Eh ren adsyn jeh cloan Israel y phriceil:

English: And gave them for the potter's field, as the Lord appointed me.
Manx: 10 As hug ad ad son magher fer-ny-craie, myr va’n Chiarn er n’oardaghey dooys.)

English: And Jesus stood before the governor: and the governor asked him, saying, Art thou the King of the Jews? And Jesus said unto him, Thou sayest.
Manx: 11 As hass Yeesey kiongoyrt y chiannoort, as dênee yn kiannoort jeh, gra, Nee uss ree ny Hewnyn? As dooyrt Yeesey rish, T’ow uss dy ghra eh.

English: And when he was accused of the chief priests and elders, he answered nothing.
Manx: 12 As tra v’eh er ny chassid liorish ny ard-saggyrtyn as y chanstyr, cha dug Eh ansoor erbee daue.

English: Then said Pilate unto him, Hearest thou not how many things they witness against thee?
Manx: 13 Eisht dooyrt Pilate rish, Nagh vel oo clashtyn cre whilleen red t’ad shoh dy hoilshaghey dt’oi?

English: And he answered him to never a word; insomuch that the governor marvelled greatly.
Manx: 14 As cha dug Eh un ockle dy ansoor da, ayns wheesh as dy ghow yn kiannoort yindyss mooar.

English: Now at that feast the governor was wont to release unto the people a prisoner, whom they would.
Manx: 15 Nish ec y eailley shen va’n kiannoort cliaghtey feaysley daue pryssoonagh erbee dy bailloo.

English: And they had then a notable prisoner, called Barabbas.
Manx: 16 As va oc ec y traa shen ard phryssoonagh va enmyssit Barabbas.

English: Therefore when they were gathered together, Pilate said unto them, Whom will ye that I release unto you? Barabbas, or Jesus which is called Christ?
Manx: 17 Shen-y-fa tra v’ad er nyn jaglym cooidjagh, dooyrt Pilate roo, Quoi sailliu mee dy eaysley diu? Barabbas, ny Yeesey, ta enmyssit Creest?

English: For he knew that for envy they had delivered him.
Manx: 18 Son va fyss echey dy nee ayns goanlys v’ad er ny livrey Eh seose.

English: When he was set down on the judgment seat, his wife sent unto him, saying, Have thou nothing to do with that just man: for I have suffered many things this day in a dream because of him.
Manx: 19 Tra v’eh erreish soie sheese er stoyl y vriwnys, hug e ven fys huggey, gra, Ny bee veg ayds dy yannoo rish y dooinney cairagh shen: son ta mish er hurranse ymmodee dy reddyn jiu ayns my chadley, kyndagh rish.

English: But the chief priests and elders persuaded the multitude that they should ask Barabbas, and destroy Jesus.
Manx: 20 Agh choyrlee ny ard-saggyrtyn as y chanstyr yn pobble ad dy yannoo aghin son Barabbas, as Yeesey y choyrt gy baase.

English: The governor answered and said unto them, Whether of the twain will ye that I release unto you? They said, Barabbas.
Manx: 21 Dansoor y kiannoort as dooyrt Eh roo, Quoi jeh’n jees sailliu mee dy eaysley diu? Dooyrt adsyn, Barabbas.

English: Pilate saith unto them, What shall I do then with Jesus which is called Christ? They all say unto him, Let him be crucified.
Manx: 22 Dooyrt Pilate roo, Cre nee’m eisht rish Yeesey, ta enmyssit Creest? Dooyrt ad ooilley rish, Lhig da v’er ny chrossey.

English: And the governor said, Why, what evil hath he done? But they cried out the more, saying, Let him be crucified.
Manx: 23 As dooyrt y kiannoort, Cre’n-oyr, cre t’eh er n’yannoo dy holk? Agh deïe adsyn ny smoo, gra, Lig da v’er ny chrossey.

English: When Pilate saw that he could prevail nothing, but that rather a tumult was made, he took water, and washed his hands before the multitude, saying, I am innocent of the blood of this just person: see ye to it.
Manx: 24 ¶ Tra honnick Pilate nagh row geill er ny chur da, agh dy row ad aarloo dy irree magh, ghow Eh ushtey, as nee Eh e laueyn kiongoyrt rish y pobble, gra, Ta mish neu-chyndagh jeh fuill yn persoon cairagh shen, jeeagh-jee shiuish da.

English: Then answered all the people, and said, His blood be on us, and on our children.
Manx: 25 Eisht dansoor ooilley’n pobble, gra, Yn uill echey dy row orrinyn, as er nyn gloan.

English: Then released he Barabbas unto them: and when he had scourged Jesus, he delivered him to be crucified.
Manx: 26 ¶ Eisht deaysle Eh Barabbas daue; as tra v’eh er chustey Yeesey, livrey Eh Eh dy ve er ny chrossey.

English: Then the soldiers of the governor took Jesus into the common hall, and gathered unto him the whole band of soldiers.
Manx: 27 Eisht hug sidooryn y chiannoort lhieu Yeesey gys hall y vriwnys, as deïe ad er y slane sheshaght jeh ny sidooryn.

English: And they stripped him, and put on him a scarlet robe.
Manx: 28 As rooisht ad Eh, as hug ad er coamrey scarleod.

English: And when they had platted a crown of thorns, they put it upon his head, and a reed in his right hand: and they bowed the knee before him, and mocked him, saying, Hail, King of the Jews
Manx: 29 ¶ As tra v’ad er fee attey dy ghrineyn, hug ad eh er y chione echey, as cuirtliagh ayns y laue yesh echey: as chroym ad nyn ghlioonyn kiongoyrt rish, as chraid ad mysh, gra, Dy vannee, Ree ny Hewnyn.

English: And they spit upon him, and took the reed, and smote him on the head.
Manx: 30 As chew ad shellaghyn er, as ghow ad y chuirtliagh, as woail ad Eh er y chione.

English: And after that they had mocked him, they took the robe off from him, and put his own raiment on him, and led him away to crucify him.
Manx: 31 As erreish daue v’er chraidey mysh, ghow ad yn coymrey reeoil jeh, as hug ad e gharmad hene er, as leeid ad Eh ersooyl dy chrossey Eh.

English: And as they came out, they found a man of Cyrene, Simon by name: him they compelled to bear his cross.
Manx: 32 As myr haink ad magh, hooar ad dooinney jeh Cyrene, va enmyssit Simon: eshyn ren ad y eaginaghey dy ymmyrkey e chrosh.

English: And when they were come unto a place called Golgotha, that is to say, a place of a skull,
Manx: 33 As tra v’ad er jeet gys ynnyd ta enmyssit Golgotha, ta shen dy ghra, ynnyd bollag,

English: They gave him vinegar to drink mingled with gall: and when he had tasted thereof, he would not drink.
Manx: 34 Hug ad da vinegar dy iu, as gall ny-chione: as tra v’eh er vlashtyn eh, cha ballish giu.

English: And they crucified him, and parted his garments, casting lots: that it might be fulfilled which was spoken by the prophet, They parted my garments among them, and upon my vesture did they cast lots.
Manx: 35 As ren ad Eh y chrossey, as reynn ad e gharmadyn, tilgey lottyn: dy voddagh shen ve cooilleenit va loayrit liorish y phadeyr, Reynn ad my gharmadyn nyn mast’ oc, as er my chooat ren ad lottyn y hilgey.

English: And sitting down they watched him there;
Manx: 36 As hoie ad sheese as watch ad Eh ayns shen.

English: And set up over his head his accusation written, THIS IS JESUS THE KING OF THE JEWS.
Manx: 37 As hoie ad harrish e chione oyr e vaaish scruit, SHOH YEESEY REE NY HEWNYN.

English: Then were there two thieves crucified with him, one on the right hand, and another on the left.
Manx: 38 Eisht va daa vaarlagh er ny chrossey marish: yn derrey yeh er y laue yesh, as y jeh elley er y laue chiare.

English: And they that passed by reviled him, wagging their heads,
Manx: 39 ¶ As doltooan y vooinjer va goll shiaghey Eh, craa nyn ging,

English: And saying, Thou that destroyest the temple, and buildest it in three days, save thyself. If thou be the Son of God, come down from the cross.
Manx: 40 As gra, Uss ta lieggal y chiamble, as dy hroggal eh reesht ayns tree laa, saue oo hene: my she Mac Yee oo, tar neose jeh’n chrosh.

English: Likewise also the chief priests mocking him, with the scribes and elders, said,
Manx: 41 Myr shen myrgeddin ren ny ard-saggyrtyn craidey mysh, marish ny scruderyn as y chanstyr, as dooyrt ad,

English: He saved others; himself he cannot save. If he be the King of Israel, let him now come down from the cross, and we will believe him.
Manx: 42 Haue Eh feallagh elley, Eh hene cha vod Eh hauail: my she ree Israel Eh, lig da cheet neose jeh’n chrosh, as nee mad credjal ayn.

English: He trusted in God; let him deliver him now, if he will have him: for he said, I am the Son of God.
Manx: 43 Hreisht Eh ayns Jee; lig da Eh y livrey nish my sallish Eh: son dooyrt Eh, She Mac Yee mee.

English: The thieves also, which were crucified with him, cast the same in his teeth.
Manx: 44 Hilg ny maarlee myrgeddin v’er nyn grossey marish yn leid cheddin er.

English: Now from the sixth hour there was darkness over all the land unto the ninth hour.
Manx: 45 Nish veih yn cheyoo oor, va dorraghys harrish ooilley’n cheer, gys yn nuyoo oor.

English: And about the ninth hour Jesus cried with a loud voice, saying, Eli, Eli, lama sabachthani? that is to say, My God, my God, why hast thou forsaken me?
Manx: 46 As mygeayrt yn nuyoo oor, deïe Yeesey lesh ard choraa, gra, Eli, Eli, lama sabacthani? ta shen dy ghra, My Yee, My Yee, cre’n fa t’ow er my hreigeil?

English: Some of them that stood there, when they heard that, said, This man calleth for Elias.
Manx: 47 Dooyrt paart jeusyn va nyn shassoo ayns shen, tra cheayll ad shen, Ta’n dooinney shoh geamagh er Elias.

English: And straightway one of them ran, and took a spunge, and filled it with vinegar, and put it on a reed, and gave him to drink.
Manx: 48 As chelleeragh roih fer jeu, as ghow Eh spunge, as lhieen Eh eh lesh vinegar, as hug Eh eh er cuirtliagh, as heeyn Eh eh huggey dy iu.

English: The rest said, Let be, let us see whether Elias will come to save him.
Manx: 49 Dooyrt y vooinjer elley, Faag-jee eh, hee mad jig Elias dy hauail Eh.

English: Jesus, when he had cried again with a loud voice, yielded up the ghost.
Manx: 50 ¶ Tra va Yeesey er n’eamagh reesht lesh ard choraa, phaart Eh.

English: And, behold, the veil of the temple was rent in twain from the top to the bottom; and the earth did quake, and the rocks rent;
Manx: 51 As cur-my-ner, va’n coodaghey va eddyr y chiamble as yn ynnyd casherick rapit veih my chielley, veih’n vullagh gys y laare; as ren y thalloo craa, as ny creggyn scoltey,

English: And the graves were opened; and many bodies of the saints which slept arose,
Manx: 52 As va ny oaiaghyn er nyn vosley, as ren ymmodee jeh kirp ny nooghyn va nyn gadley, girree seose,

English: And came out of the graves after his resurrection, and went into the holy city, and appeared unto many.
Manx: 53 As cheet ass ny hoaiaghyn oc, lurg yn irree-seose-reesht echey, as goll stiagh ayns yn ard-valley casherick, as ad hene y hoilshaghey da ymmodee.

English: Now when the centurion, and they that were with him, watching Jesus, saw the earthquake, and those things that were done, they feared greatly, saying, Truly this was the Son of God.
Manx: 54 Nish tra honnick yn captan-keead, as adsyn va marish watchal Yeesey, yn craa-thallooin, as ny reddyn v’er jeet gy kione, ghow ad aggle mooar, gra, Dy firrinagh shoh va Mac Yee.

English: And many women were there beholding afar off, which followed Jesus from Galilee, ministering unto him:
Manx: 55 As va ymmodee mraane ayns shen (va dy akin Eh foddey vow) va er n’eiyrt er Yeesey veih Galilee, as er hirveish er.

English: Among which was Mary Magdalene, and Mary the mother of James and Joses, and the mother of Zebedees children.
Manx: 56 Nyn mast’ oc va Moirrey Malaine, as Moirrey moir James as Joses, as moir cloan Zebedee.

English: When the even was come, there came a rich man of Arimathaea, named Joseph, who also himself was Jesus’ disciple:
Manx: 57 Tra va’n fastyr er jeet, haink dooinney berchagh jeh Arimathea, va enmyssit Joseph, va myrgeddin Eh hene er chredjal ayns Yeesey.

English: He went to Pilate, and begged the body of Jesus. Then Pilate commanded the body to be delivered.
Manx: 58 Hie Eh shoh gys Pilate, as ren Eh aghin son corp Yeesey: eisht hug Pilate saarey yn corp dy ve er ny livrey.

English: And when Joseph had taken the body, he wrapped it in a clean linen cloth,
Manx: 59 As tra va Joseph er ghoaill yn corp, hoïll Eh eh ayns aanrit glen,

English: And laid it in his own new tomb, which he had hewn out in the rock: and he rolled a great stone to the door of the sepulchre, and departed.
Manx: 60 As doanluck Eh eh ayns yn oaie noa echey hene, v’eh er ny chley ayns creg: as rowll Eh clagh vooar er beeal yn oaie, as jimmee Eh roish.

English: And there was Mary Magdalene, and the other Mary, sitting over against the sepulchre.
Manx: 61 As va Moirrey Malaine, as Moirrey elley, nyn soie jeeragh er yn oaie.

English: Now the next day, that followed the day of the preparation, the chief priests and Pharisees came together unto Pilate,
Manx: 62 ¶ Nish yn nah laa lurg laa yn aarlaghey, haink ny ard-saggyrtyn as ny Phariseeyn cooidjagh gys Pilate,

English: Saying, Sir, we remember that that deceiver said, while he was yet alive, After three days I will rise again.
Manx: 63 Gra, Vainshtyr, ta cooinaghtyn ain dy dooyrt yn moltere shen, choud as v’eh foast bio, Lurg three laa neem’s girree reesht.

English: Command therefore that the sepulchre be made sure until the third day, lest his disciples come by night, and steal him away, and say unto the people, He is risen from the dead: so the last error shall be worse than the first.
Manx: 64 Cur saarey er-y-fa shen yn oaie dy ve jeant shickyr, derrey yn tress laa, er aggle dy jig yn vooinjer t’er ve sheer geiyrt er ayns yn oie, as dy geid ad Eh ersooyl, as dy jir ad rish yn pobble, T’eh er n’irree veih ny merriu: myr shen bee’n molteraght s’jerree ny smessey na’n chied volteraght.

English: Pilate said unto them, Ye have a watch: go your way, make it as sure as ye can.
Manx: 65 Dooyrt Pilate roo, Ta watch eu, immee-jee reue, jean-jee cha shickyr jeh as oddys shiu.

English: So they went, and made the sepulchre sure, sealing the stone, and setting a watch.
Manx: 66 Myr shen hie ad as ren ad yn oaie shickyr, sealal y chlagh, as soiaghey watch.
CAB. XXVIII.

English: In the end of the sabbath, as it began to dawn toward the first day of the week, came Mary Magdalene and the other Mary to see the sepulchre.
Manx: Tra va’n doonaght ec kione, as y laa toshiaght soilshaghey er y chied laa jeh’n chaghtin, haink Moirrey Malaine, as Moirrey elley dy voddagh ad yn oaie y akin.

English: And, behold, there was a great earthquake: for the angel of the Lord descended from heaven, and came and rolled back the stone from the door, and sat upon it.
Manx: 2 As cur-my-ner, va craa-thallooin mooar ayn; son va ainle y Chiarn er jeet neose veih niau, as er jeet as er rowlal back y chlagh jeh beeal yn oaie, as er hoie er.

English: His countenance was like lightning, and his raiment white as snow:
Manx: 3 Va’n eddin echey goll-rish y tendeil, as e choamrey gial myr y sniaghtey.

English: And for fear of him the keepers did shake, and became as dead men.
Manx: 4 As ayns aggle roish, ren y vooinjer va watchal craa, as haink ad dy ve myr deiney marroo.

English: And the angel answered and said unto the women, Fear not ye: for I know that ye seek Jesus, which was crucified.
Manx: 5 As dreggyr yn ainle, as dooyrt Eh rish ny mraane; Ny gow-jee aggle: son ta fys aym dy vel shiu shirrey Yeesey, v’er ny chrossey.

English: He is not here: for he is risen, as he said. Come, see the place where the Lord lay.
Manx: 6 Cha vel Eh ayns shoh, son t’eh er n’irree, myr dooyrt Eh hene: tar-jee, jeeagh-jee er yn ynnyd raad va’n Chiarn oanluckit.

English: And go quickly, and tell his disciples that he is risen from the dead; and, behold, he goeth before you into Galilee; there shall ye see him: lo, I have told you.
Manx: 7 As immee-jee dy tappee, as insh-jee dauseyn va sheer geiyrt er, dy vel Eh er n’irree veih ny merriu; as cur-my-ner, t’eh goll reue gys Galilee, ayns shen hee shiu Eh; cur-my-ner, ta mish er n’insh diu.

English: And they departed quickly from the sepulchre with fear and great joy; and did run to bring his disciples word.
Manx: 8 As jimmee ad dy tappee veih’n oaie lesh aggle as boggey mooar, as roih ad dy chur lhieu yn naight gys e ostyllyn.

English: And as they went to tell his disciples, behold, Jesus met them, saying, All hail. And they came and held him by the feet, and worshipped him.
Manx: 9 ¶ As myr v’ad goll dy insh eh da e ostyllyn, cur-my-ner, haink Yeesey nyn guail, gra, Dy vannee diu. As haink ad, as chum ad Eh er y chassyn, as hug ad ooashley da.

English: Then said Jesus unto them, Be not afraid: go tell my brethren that they go into Galilee, and there shall they see me.
Manx: 10 Eisht dooyrt Yeesey roo, Ny gow-jee aggle: immee-jee as abbyr-jee rish my vraaraghyn ad dy gholl gys Galilee, as ayns shen hee ad mee.

English: Now when they were going, behold, some of the watch came into the city, and shewed unto the chief priests all the things that were done.
Manx: 11 ¶ Nish tra v’ad goll, cur-my-ner, haink paart jeh’n watch gys yn ard-valley, as hoilshee ad da ny ard-saggyrtyn ooilley ny reddyn v’er jeet gy kione:

English: And when they were assembled with the elders, and had taken counsel, they gave large money unto the soldiers,
Manx: 12 As tra v’adsyn as y chanstyr er nyn jaglym cooidjagh, as er chur nyn goyrle dy-cheilley, hug ad sim mooar dy argid da ny sidooryn,

English: Saying, Say ye, His disciples came by night, and stole him away while we slept.
Manx: 13 Gra, Abbyr-jee shiuish, Haink e ostyllyn ayns yn oie, as gheid ad Eh ersooyl choud as va shin nyn gadley.

English: And if this come to the governor’s ears, we will persuade him, and secure you.
Manx: 14 As my chlinnys y kiannoort jeh, ver mainyn er credjal dy vel eh firrinagh, as freillee mad shiuish sauchey.

English: So they took the money, and did as they were taught: and this saying is commonly reported among the Jews until this day.
Manx: 15 Myr shen ghow ad yn argid, as ren ad myr v’er ny chur roue: as ta’n raa shoh dy cadjin er ny insh magh mastey ny Hewnyn gys y laa t’ayn jiu.

English: Then the eleven disciples went away into Galilee, into a mountain where Jesus had appointed them.
Manx: 16 ¶ Eisht hie yn un ostyl yeig roue gys Galilee, gys slieau raad va Yeesey er n’oardaghey daue.

English: And when they saw him, they worshipped him: but some doubted.
Manx: 17 As tra honnick ad Eh, hug ad ooashley da: agh va paart imneagh ayns nyn gredjue.

English: And Jesus came and spake unto them, saying, All power is given unto me in heaven and in earth.
Manx: 18 As haink Yeesey, as loayr Eh roo, gra, Ta dy chooilley phooar er ny chur dou ayns niau as er y thalloo.

English: Go ye therefore, and teach all nations, baptizing them in the name of the Father, and of the Son, and of the Holy Ghost:
Manx: 19 ¶ Immee-jee er-y-fa shen as ynsee-jee dy chooilley ashoon, as bashtee-jee ad ayns ennym yn Ayr, as y Vac, as y spyrryd Noo:

English: Teaching them to observe all things whatsoever I have commanded you: and, lo, I am with you alway, even unto the end of the world. Amen.
Manx: 20 Gynsaghey daue dy reaylley dy chooilley nhee cre-erbee ta mish er chur ayns saarey diu: as cur-my-ner, Ta mish mêriu kinjagh, gys eer jerrey’n theihll.
Amen.
